story: The trial this week of video-link consultations with an NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde consultant orthopaedic surgeon for five Campbeltown patients could be the first step in changing that.People#s time is valuable and the Skype-like calls mean that neither the patients nor the medical professionals have to travel for hours to attend appointments.The cost to both iniduals and the NHS of patients travelling to Glasgow via bus and plane must be signicant.And there has never been greater awareness of the issue of climate change, with the recent Extinction Rebellion protests in London making national headlines.Thousands of protesters blocked off roads in the capital city and called on the government for action to reduce carbon emissions to zero by .The wonders of modern technology could provide a win-win solution # giving people easier access to medical care as well as reducing carbon emissions.

title: letter insufficient consultation on pylon scheme
story: I was out and about in Tarbert recently getting updated by my constituents and local businesses on many pressing local issues.With the village of Tarbert heading into the busy tourist season, the lack of parking spaces in certain areas will become more and more prevalent, all the more so with the ever increasing amount of traffic going towards Islay.I will continue to seek local advice on how to resolve Tarbert#s parking challenges and make sure they are relayed on to our roads department.While the upgrades to the electrical grid capacity are much needed I have been listening to concerns about the plans to erect numerous huge pylons along the picturesque Tarbert skyline.Many locals have commented that there has been insufficient public consultation and many of my constituents have pointed out that with some changes to pylon positioning much of the adverse visual impact could be mitigated.I have also been sent pictures and videos of the cemetery road which has numerous large potholes and craters.Many Tarbert residents have informed me thatwe, in the council, cannot help to provide a solution then a community solution should be looked at.It was great to catch up with local residents in Tarbert and I look forward to being back there very soon.Coucillor Alastair Redman,

title: deal-reached-to-sell-part-of-former-cockenzie-power-station-site
story: However, the size of the site which has been set aside is understood to be less than a third of the land originally proposed by the company.The local authority has announced that it has signed an options agreement with Inch Cape for a ldquosmall part of the former power station site, which is understood to be about seven acres of the -acre site.It has also agreed to the land used being to the far west of the site originally planned and set back from the coastline.Inch Cape won planning permission to build the substation, which will bring energy onshore from an offshore wind farm, earlier this year after Scottish Ministers controversially called in the planning application and granted approval.The original plans from Inch Cape cover a wider -acre site on the land on an area which was part of the footprint of the former power station itself.Concerns raised about the impact it would have on developing the rest of the site, which was purchased by East Lothian Council from ScottishPower last March, had been raised, as well as the visual impact on the coast.Inch Cape has consistently pledged to reduce the size of the substation, which will be remotely operated, to as small a footprint as possible.The reduced site was welcomed by East Lothian MSP Iain Gray, who had opposed the planning decision being take out of local authority hands.He said: ldquoHowever, with permission for the substation granted by ministers, this is a good outcome, with the size of the construction signicantly reduced and the actual site moved away from the waterfront.ldquoEast Lothian Council has minimised the area they had to sell, and hopefully that means progress can now be made on finding the right opportunity to create jobs and boost the local economy.Bryan Hickman, chairman of Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council, which opposed the site during the Scottish Government Reporterrsquos enquiry, said: ldquoInch Cape have consistently consulted with us on all matters relating to this application. We look forward to seeing a final plan showing the overall design.However, Brian Weddell, chairman of neighbouring Prestonpans Community Council, which also opposed the substation, raised concerns about the decision to sell the land and its long-term future.Prestonpans Community Council is lobbying for a cruise terminal to be based at the site.Mr Weddell said: ldquoIt remains the view of the Prestonpans community that the transformer is heading for the wrong location.ldquoHowever, we recognise that construction is going ahead regardless and we need to plan for the future.ldquoWe welcome the smaller footprint and believe the cruise ship terminal could easily be accommodated on the adjacent site.ldquoWe are concerned about the sale of this valuable site and the loss of public ownership what happens in  years when the wind farm is decommissioned Monica Patterson, depute chief executive of East Lothian Council, said: ldquoWe are pleased to have reached an agreement which will enable a substantially smaller area of the western site to be purchased from the council.ldquoThis means signicant land will remain available for opportunities to boost the local economy and create employment opportunities.Guy Madgwick, CEO of Red Rock Power, which owns Inch Cape, told the Courier: ldquoThis is a key milestone for the Inch Cape project and a signicant step forward in our plans to deliver a project with such national economic importance as well as contributing signicantly to Scotlandrsquos renewable energy targets.The purchase of the site will follow the progression of the Inch Cape Offshore Wind Farm project as a whole.Further details of the option agreement are commercially confidential at this stage.

title: new-exhibition-highlights-history-of-musselburgh-athletic-fc
story: The display was officially opened by Billy Brown, a former Hearts and Bradford City manager, who comes from Musselburgh and is a former Musselburgh Athletic manager, at a reception in the Old Town Hall.On show at the High Street museum is a iety of memorabilia relating to lsquoThe Burghrsquo, including trophies, medals, strips, pennants and photographs. New information boards by graphic designer Hazel Allison, of New Street, and local company Eastern make easy reading for visitors.Football stars featured in the exhibition, which runs until June , include former Scotland manager Willie Ormond, who lived in Musselburgh.Players and managers past and present joined other guests, including Councillor John McMillan, Provost of East Lothian Irene Tait, chair of Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council representatives from the Honest Tounrsquos Association and the  Honest Lad Conor Scott and Honest Lass Katie McLaren at the official opening last week.They included -year-old Musselburgh man Bobby Wilson, the holder of a Scottish League Cup winners medal from , who had travelled from his home in Carnoustie. He went on to play for Aberdeen after leaving Musselburgh Athletic.Club chairman Karl Cleghorn praised the support given by Simon Fairnie, of Musselburgh Museum and Heritage Group, and other volunteers at Musselburgh Museum, adding that it was hoped that local schoolchildren would visit the exhibition to learn more about the club, which was formed in .Its history in the Honest Toun goes back a lot further and its links to earlier clubs, such as Musselburgh Fern and Musselburgh Bruntonians, can be traced back to .Over the years, Burgh have had a good number of league title and cup wins, including in recent times the St Michaelrsquos Cup, League Cup and Brown Cup. The team have been finalists in the Scottish Junior Cup twice in the last eight years.Having played in the junior football leagues for more than  years, Burgh are now a member of the East of Scotland League.Mr Cleghorn said the move had been a ldquohuge transition for the club.ldquoVery pleasingly, by a lot of hard work by the team, previous manager and new manager, we have got into the top five of our league, which qualies us for the big league next season, he said.ldquoEvery other week at Olive Bank we are going to have a big team like Linlithgow, Borsquoness, Broxburn, Newtongrange, Tranent, Dunbar and Bonnyrigg.ldquoThese are big things for the towns and communities ndash we have got some numbers coming back to the football and the quality on the park is really good.The club has applied for membership of the Scottish Football Association and there are many improvements under way at their stadium.ldquoThis is an equal club ndash a community club, stressed Mr Cleghorn.Norman Murray, a member of the clubrsquos committee, said children from Campie Primary School were making use of the ground at Olive Bank for recreation and sports, and it was hoped to open the facility up to others in June and July for events such as concerts.Mr Cleghorn added: ldquoOnce the club gets the SFA licence, they can play in the Scottish Cup then.ldquoWe will be continuing to look to support Musselburgh Windsor and bring up ladies football teams.

title: former-boxer-in-talks-with-actor-about-turning-debut-novel-into-a-movie
story: Alex Brown, , owner of Ideal Flooring Solutions, recently travelled to London for a meeting with Robert Cavanah over the plan to bring his book Hit Me to the big screen.Mr Cavanah has had starring roles in a wide range of productions including Cracker, Blue Dove, Cadfael, Hamish Macbeth, Kavanagh QC, Rose and Maloney, Rebus, Silent Witness, Highlander: The Raven, Casualty, DCI Banks, Waterloo Road, The Bill, The Governor, The Borgias and Hatfields  McCoys.He played Robert Stevenson in the BBC television drama-documentary series Seven Wonders of the Industrial World, which chronicled the design and construction of the Bell Rock Lighthouse.Mr Cavanah, who was born in Edinburgh, also played Adam Carnegie in The Royal for three series and Tommy Grant in EastEnders.He starred in the  ITV version of Wuthering Heights as Heathclf. He played Ian in Emmerdale and guest starred in Outlander.His film acting credits include Soccer Mom, Birthday, Fall of the Essex Boys, AB Negative, Lara Croft: Tomb Raider ndash The Cradle of Le and Sahara.Hit Me, the darkly comic crime thriller written by Mr Brown, an ex-boxer, tells the story of former boxer Barnabas Wild, who is diagnosed with terminal cancer and ends up in the fight of his le.He contacts a childhood friend, now a crime boss in Edinburgh, to have a hit put on him as the thought of dying in a hospital bed proves too much.He then receives an urgent call from a consultant at the hospital who explains an error in recent test results. He does not have cancer, but the crime boss has gone missing.The main character is named after a clergyman who served for  years at the former Tranent Methodist Church, which was transformed into the Bronx Boxing Gym, which is owned by Mr Brown.Mr Cavanah said: ldquoAfter reading Hit Me, I felt quickly the genre, colour of the characters and comedic inclination would make it a really enjoyable movie.ldquoI love anything that promotes Scottish talent, culture and character. This does all of that.Mr Brown is set for another meeting with Mr Cavanah in London in July.Possible actors have already been discussed to play the characters.He said: ldquoI am very excited that someone like Robert Cavanah, whom I have watched on TV for many years, is showing such interest and passion about my book Hit Me, not only as a book but about it becoming a movie.ldquoWe got on really well together and I could really see the movie in my mind as we discussed it during our meeting.ldquoI am a bit overwhelmed at the thought of going to London to spend a few weeks with Robert but I am also really looking forward to it and I am up for the challenge.ldquoWho would have thought it a year ago that I would be arranging to work on a treatment that could lead to a movie with a star like Robert, whom I feel is definitely the person who is right for the project Blackwellrsquos Bookshop in Edinburgh will appear in a new trailer that is being produced for Hit Me which will be shown on YouTube, Facebook and Twitter.The novel in eBook and paperback is available from Amazon.

title: co-op-announces-prestonpans-store-is-to-close
story: The firm employs  people at the supermarket at Links Shopping Centre on High Street.The news has been met with dismay in the community.Ward councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell said: ldquoI was sorry to hear about the closure of the Co-op in Prestonpans.ldquoIts late opening hours save local people having to travel out of town.ldquoIt also plays an important role in bringing people onto High Street and helping sustain other businesses.ldquoIt will be a worrying time for the employees, and it is important they are given full support to find other employment.Ms OrsquoDonnell added that she would like to see more investment in Prestonpans to help nurture local businesses and create employment.Fellow ward councillor Lachlan Bruce said: ldquoThis isnrsquot welcome news.ldquoObviously, we want that space open and operating so that it gives facilities for locals to use and also provides much-needed employment.The councillor said that he would be contacting the owners of the site to find out who the next tenant would be.Brian Weddell, chairman of Prestonpans Community Council, added: ldquoWhilst it is very disappointing that the Co-op are closing their store at Preston Links, it strengthens Prestonpans Community Councilrsquos case for a fundamental review of our High Street.ldquoPrestonpans is one of East Lothianrsquos largest towns and deserves a High Street that can attract local shoppers and serve visitors along the John Muir Way.A spokesperson for Co-op said: ldquoThe Co-op is moving forward with real purpose and momentum, and while this usually involves the opening of new stores, we also have to make dficult decisions.ldquoAfter careful consideration, our store on High Street in Prestonpans will close. The last day of trading is expected to be in November.ldquoThis is no way a reflection of the hard work of colleagues, who have been informed, and every effort will be made to find alternative roles for them.ldquoWe would like to thank the community for its support over the years.

title: jaimes-brave-abseil-in-tribute-to-her-dad
story: Jaime Sutherland, of Rowanhill Close, Port Seton, is taking on the abseil in June in aid of Chest, Heart and Stroke Scotland ndash and in tribute to her dad Dave, a civilian police worker, who suffered a fatal heart attack when he was just  years old.Jaime told the Courier: ldquoI saw an advert for abseiling down the bridge on Facebook.ldquoIrsquod already been thinking about doing something to raise money for charity and this seemed the perfect thing.ldquoMy dad passed away in  and I wanted to do something in his memory.ldquoIrsquom not usually a daredevil, but Irsquom not too bad with heights.Jaime has already raised pound through her Everyday Hero page on Facebook.She added: ldquoAll my mates think that Irsquom a bit mad and I think my mum was shocked when I told her what I wanted to do. Irsquom excited, though.As well as studying for her Highers, the -year-old coaches youngsters at Tranent Amateur Swimming Club, as well as working for Splash Start, and she is a leguard at Seton Sands Holiday Park. She was also named Junior Volunteer of the Year at the Tranent and District Community Sport Club Awards in .Mum Lynn added: ldquoIrsquom extremely proud of her.ldquoI know that she suffered anxiety after her dad died, it was a dficult time, so to see her reach this point is amazing.ldquoShersquos always wanted to help other people and has shown maturity beyond her years.ldquoShe is extremely hard-working and a great example at age  to younger people.Jaimersquos younger brother Andrew, , is also extremely supportive of his sister, making a donation to her page with his own money, writing: ldquoSo proud of you sissy, good luck.The family are also organising a disco on June  to help raise extra money for the cause.Anyone wanting to help with raffle donations should email lynncsutherland@aolTo support Jaimersquos abseil, which takes place on June , visit here.

title: information-sessions-being-held-about-future-of-cockenzie-power-station-site
story: The council, which owns the land at the former power station, is holding sessions on Wednesday, April , -pm at the Port Seton Centre Thursday, April , am-pm at the Pennypit Centre, Prestonpans Thursday, April , -pm at Tesco Extra in Musselburgh Friday, April , - pm in the Co-op at Links Shopping Centre in Prestonpans and Saturday, April , am-pm at Haddington Farmersrsquo Market on Court Street.The council said: ldquoItrsquos an excellent opportunity to find out more about future ambitions for one of East Lothianrsquos key strategic economic development sites.Also next week, Inch Cape is heading to Prestonpans and Port Seton to also discuss the former power station site and the electrical substation it will build on a portion of the site.Visualisations of the onshore transmission works will be on display with a D model of the proposed site there is a chance to give feedback.As a part of the Planning Permission in Principle , the company says it is looking to involve the community and encourage people to submit ideas for the external design, or any artwork surrounding the substation to make it more in keeping with its surroundings and more of a visitor talking point.The events take place at the Prestonpans Community Centre on Tuesday and at the Port Seton Centre next Thursday , both -pm.Local artists interested in getting involved can email inchcapewind@redrockpower

title: seven-year-old-praised-for-taking-action-to-stop-dog-fouling
story: Seven-year-old Ava Lily Davidson, a P pupil at Stoneyhill Primary School, was inspired to make her own dog poo bag dispensers after watching a TV programme on Newsround about school pupil Ivy Meager who provided them in her home town of Burnham-on-Sea.As Ava, of Clayknowes Drive, was also studying the environment in class, she wanted to do something to benefit Musselburgh.She has made her first dog poo bag dispenser out of an old plastic bottle, filling it with environmentally friendly bags for members of the public to use to clean up after their pooch.Ava has installed the first dispenser on a lamppost on Whitehill Farm Road, where her grandparents live, and is hoping to site others around Musselburgh. She is keen to put a dispenser at Whitehill Park near her school because the area is used for football and is also targeting the promenade.Her mum Stephanie said the dispenser was proving a success with dog walkers, adding: ldquoHopefully more and more people will make use of them.The anti-litter campaign Donrsquot Mess With Mussy is backing Avarsquos efforts.The dog poo dispenser has been added to a map of the town on the campaignrsquos Facebook page, which also identies locations of litter bins, recycling facilities, and electric vehicle charging points.Donrsquot Mess with Mussy organiser Melanie Roccio said: ldquoAva is a credit to the community and is setting a wonderful example to adults and children. Getting children involved in this kind of thing from a young age is the key to our future.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoWe are aware of a number of iniduals across the county who are providing poo bag dispensers across their local community to help reduce the problem of dog fouling.ldquoSome dog owners still fail to pick up after their pet, which is both unsightly and unhygienic. Any attempt to tackle this is welcome and there can be no excuses for failing to bag it and bin it.

title: haddingtons-swimming-pool-about-to-shut-for-nine-week-refurbishment
story: One of East Lothianrsquos original sports facilities lsquoHaddington Swimming Poolrsquo, as it was first known as, opened its doors in September .The much-loved site at the Aubigny Sports Centre consists of a four-lane swimming pool and East Lothianrsquos only dedicated infant pool.Currently the facility welcomes about , bathers to the pool each week for swimming lessons, AquaFit classes, club training, school and public use.Operators enjoyleisure posted on Facebook: "After  years, Aubigny Sports Centres swimming pool hall is getting a well-earned facelt."The swimming pools and health suite will close on Tuesday for nine weeks to complete a refurbishment of the pool hall."Donrsquot worry, the rest of the sports centre will remain open for all your gym, fitness and sporting activities."The refurbishment will include both essential maintenance and interior deacutecor upgrades.The refurbishment plans include the complete replacement of custom-fit ceiling window  and a new roof covering.Inside the pool hall, following a complete drain of both pools, a light and bright ceiling covering will replace the outdated wood cladding.A new energy efficient lighting scheme will be fitted which will transform the look and feel of the facility for the benefit of all users.Furthermore, existing wall tiles will be replaced with wall liner  to complete the fresh new look.The final day of the works is scheduled to be Friday, June .Swimming lessons there are scheduled to resume on Monday, July .

title: honest-lad-and-honest-lass-candidates-set-for-elections
story: Seeking election for  are: Claire Dougal,  Aidan Maguire,  Michael Morrison,  and Abbie Thomson, .Michael has served as an attendant for the past two years and Claire was also an attendant at last yearrsquos festival, supporting Honest Lad Conor Scott and Honest Lass Katie McLaren as part of the official party.Also throwing their hats into the ring this year are Aidan and Abbie, who are also delighted to be standing as candidates.The following polling stations are open for voting Friday: Brunton Hall concourse, am-pm Musselburgh Primary Care Centre, am to pm Musselburgh Museum, .am until pm Musselburgh East Community Centre, pm until pm Musselburgh Rugby Club, pm to pmWallyford Community Centre, pm to pm Whitecraig Community Centre, pm to pm.Each polling station is operated by members of festival organisers the Honest Tounrsquos Association and overseen by volunteers from the Rotary Club of Musselburgh and Old Musselburgh Club. At the end of the election, votes are counted by an independent team and supervised by a representative of each candidate.The four candidates are now working hard to canvas for the publicrsquos vote by selling membership cards costing pound throughout the community.Once purchased, these cards can then be presented at one of the listed polling stations on election day for votes to be cast.The result of the election will initially be declared within The Brunton to the candidates, their families, local councillors and the associationrsquos committee before being announced publicly from the outside balcony of the building at about pm.In traditional style, the new Honest Lad, Honest Lass and attendants will be paraded around the town in an open carriage led by the Boysrsquo Brigade Pipe Band. Everyone is welcome to go along to hear the announcement and help get the  Musselburgh Festival off to a great start.A disco will take place in Musselburgh Rugby Club which will be open from .pm, with entry pound.Alison Elgin, association president, said: ldquoWe have four excellent candidates and they are all working hard to canvas votes. We do all that we can to ensure that the election is as fair and transparent as is possible, and we are really proud that the people of Musselburgh vote for their Honest Lad and Honest Lass each year.ldquoPlans are well under way for Festival Week  with events which will hopefully appeal to everyone."This year we are working with Musselburgh Racecourse on their Community Race Day which will be held on Sunday, September . As a result of this, we can announce that, by voting in this yearrsquos election, you will be admitted free of charge to Musselburgh Racecourse on the day when you present your membership card which will be stamped at the polling station when you vote.This yearrsquos Musselburgh Festival will run from July  to .The candidates are:Claire DougalClaire, , was born and brought up in Whitecraig, attending Whitecraig Primary and Musselburgh Grammar Schools. She works at Pinkie Farm Shop as a general assistant. She has been a member of Musselburgh Crusaders Riding Club since she was  years old and won the youngest rider trophy at the age of . She has taken part in every Musselburgh rideout since she was eight years old and has participated in numerous fancy dress parades. She has also had the pleasure of attending numerous other townsrsquo rides and festivals over the last few years. Claire enjoys spending time with friends, family and her horse Ripper. She thoroughly enjoyed last year as an attendant, visiting local schools and businesses and representing Musselburgh in the Borders. She is looking forward to representing Musselburgh in  after a fantastic year last year.Aidan MaguireAidan, , was a pupil at Loretto RC Primary School in Musselburgh before attending St Davidrsquos High School in Dalkeith. During secondary school, he held part-time positions at TK Maxx and USC. On leaving school, he was appointed as an apprentice with Slight Joinery Ltd. Aidanrsquos interests include following national rugby and football teams as well as snowboarding, and he enjoys trying new sports.He has been a spectator of the festival, watching the rideouts and fancy dress parade with his family and friends. Aidan has a good understanding of the history behind the festival and feels that this is the right time to become more involvedMichael MorrisonMichael, , attended Musselburgh Burgh Primary School and Musselburgh Grammar School. Originally living in Carberry, he moved to Musselburgh five years ago when his grandfather retired from his candle-making business. He has been involved in ious community activities since his primary school days, having been a member of the Boysrsquo Brigade, a piper with the Boysrsquo Brigade band and a member of Musselburgh Rugby Club. He played for Musselburgh both at club and district level, and has been involved with assisting the training of junior rugby players. For the past two years, he has had the honour of supporting past Honest Lad Jamie Cameron and Honest Lad Conor Scott as their attendant, and it is his ambition to become Honest Lad himself and to represent Musselburgh. His time as attendant has prepared him well for this responsibility. Michael is currently employed as a security guard. He recently gained his bus driving qualications and is keen to become a coach driver. He is looking forward to participating in the forthcoming festival and knows how enjoyable it can be for everyone.Abbie ThomsonAbbie, , has lived in Musselburgh all her le and attended Campie Primary School and Musselburgh Grammar School, where she was a prefect in her fth and sixth year. Growing up, she attended Brownies at Pinkie School and Guides at Northesk. She is currently in her final year studying BScApplied Animal Science at Scotlandrsquos Rural University College and she is due to graduate in July. Abbie began riding at the age of  and was an active member of the local pony club. She spends most of her free time with her own horse, mucking out stables at a local livery yard or volunteering at the Riding for the Disabled Association. Having grown up watching the festival and taking part in the fancy dress parade when she was younger, Abbie is delighted to be a candidate for Honest Lass. She is looking forward to representing Musselburgh as part of the official party both at home and in the Borders.

title: former-cockenzie-power-station-site-about-to-be-put-on-open-market
story: East Lothian Council is preparing to put giant signs on the former Cockenzie Power Station land inviting potential customers to make a bid.The move comes just over a year after the council formally completed the purchase of the -acre coastline site.Public consultations on the future of the site, which includes a large area of communal land, known as the Greenhills, which is used by local communities and the former coal plant site and historic Waggonway land, were carried out over two years ago.The local authority produced a masterplan for the site based on the consultations, which it described as a ldquovision document for its future.However, neighbouring communities straddling the site have opposing views on its best future development.Prestonpans Community Council has lobbied for a cruise terminal at the former power station and the council has agreed to carry out an engineering study into its feasibility.In neighbouring Cockenzie and Port Seton, community councillors are keen to see the masterplan, which does not support a cruise port, adopted by the local authority.It sets out a range of ideas for the site, including the potential for a marina at the waterfront, business and economic sectors, and recreational land.Despite the investment into producing the masterplan and consulting the public, the only definite project confirmed for the site so far is an unmanned substation, which will bring offshore energy onto land for Inch Cape Offshore Ltd .ICOL, which are owned by Chinese State-owned company Red Rock, was granted permission for the substation after the Scottish Ministers called in its planning application shortly after East Lothian Council bought the land.The council confirmed earlier this month that is had agreed to sell part of the land to ICOL.A bid by local group the Battle of Prestonpans Heritage Trust to buy part of the land for its own heritable project has been rejected by the council.The council told the trust it had been advised against selling until ldquosuch time as the future of the whole site has been determined.Signs promoting the land for development are expected to go up on the site within the next few weeks after they were given planning approval.They will invite all enquiries about ldquoeconomic development opportunities on the site to get in touch via email.

title: opening-hours-slashed-at-three-tsbs-in-east-lothian
story: Dropping footfall has been blamed for the hours being cut at the bankrsquos branches in Haddington, North Berwick and Dunbar.The changes will come into force from the end of July and will not affect the Musselburgh TSB branch.A spokeswoman for TSB said that there had been a drop of eight per cent in customer transactions in Haddington, three per cent in Dunbar and one per cent in North Berwick.Currently, the branches in Dunbar, Haddington and North Berwick are all open from .am to .pm from Monday to Friday, with a lunch hour .-.pm.However, from the end of July, the TSB branch in Haddington will only be open Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday, while the North Berwick branch will only be open between those hours on a Tuesday and Friday, and Dunbar will be open on a Monday and Thursday.Carol Anderson, branch distribution director for Scotland at TSB, said: ldquoOur customers use banking services in dferent ways and that is why we try to adapt our offer to deliver them the best possible service, however they choose to bank.ldquoThis means investment in both branches and digital channels.ldquoWith fewer people using [the branches], we are reducing the number of hours.ldquoOur TSB Partners will be working with our customers to support them as we make this change.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of Dunbar Community Council, felt it was disappointing to see a unit on High Street not being fully utilised.Mrs Swan said: ldquoI think all banks are making decisions about how they can best operate financially.ldquoThey must have worked out their best business case is to work two days a week.ldquoI suspect some of the customers will find it sufficiently inconvenient that they will switch banks. We, as a community council, are aware of lots of people who did switch from the Royal Bank of Scotland to Bank of Scotland [when Dunbarrsquos RBS closed last year].ldquoI think it is plainly unfortunate to have a unit on High Street that is not operational five days a week.

title: unpaid-work-for-man-caught-with-scissors-in-haddington
story: James Potter, of Kirk View, was caught with a pair of scissors while on the townrsquos Monkmains Road earlier this year.Potter, , pleaded guilty to the charge when he appeared in the dock at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Thursday.Sherf John Cook decided to mark the offence by ordering Potter to carry out  hours of unpaid work in the community.Potter admitted possessing a pair of scissors at Monkmains Road, Haddington, on March .

title: chance-for-public-to-have-a-look-at-major-plans-at-dunbar-golf-club
story: The plans ndash which are an update of proposals submitted a decade ago and would complement the existing golf course ndash also include a new driving range, a nine-hole golf course, a golf academy and practice facilities.Tony Thomas, who is representing Dunbar Golf Club and CALA Management Ltd, which are behind the plans, visited the townrsquos community council ahead of the public exhibition, which takes place in the townrsquos Dunmuir Hotel between pm and pm tomorrow.Mr Thomas said alterations to the original plans, which were approved in , meant a new planning application had to be submitted.Now, amended plans have been drawn up, with hopes that a planning application could be with East Lothian Council, which would likely decide the fate of the proposals, by the autumn. Regardless of whether the plans are approved, golf will continue to be played on the -hole championship course.Mr Thomas, from East Lintonrsquos APT Planning and Development, said: ldquoIf we get the application in by September, something as relatively complex as this,we get permission this time next year we will be doing well.ldquoThe first houses would be a year later and then the clubhouse built by  for the clubhouse to opens its doors in .ldquoThe last houses would be  months on from that.The majority of the houses would be built towards Deer Park Cemetery, with about  units being built on the site of the current clubhouse.Under the plans, a new clubhouse would be built, with access coming from the A, and a nine-hole course built to the north-west, and a driving range to the east.The changes will mean a slight alteration to the layout of the course.The development will not include affordable housing as it is part of an enabling development. However, Mr Thomas stressed more than pound, would go to East Lothian Council in education contributions.Provisional designs for the properties, which are expected to be between three and five-bedroom in size, will be included in display boards at the exhibition.Details regarding the size of the hotel are still being worked out but historically the proposal was for a building with between  and  rooms.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, felt there were issues which could be addressed to enhance the proposals.She said: ldquoI just feel a sense of disappointment that the developers, who have such a wonderful opportunity, do not seem to take the opportunity to build more contemporary, innovative housing. That is my regret. It is a fantastic site but the sense of what we are going to get is a repeat of the Cala homes at Beveridge Row.Mrs Swan also noted a lot of people used the land at Deer Park for recreation.She said a previous public meeting, when the community council was consulting about East Lothian Councilrsquos local development plan, had highlighted a desire for improved connections throughout the town.She added: ldquoThe public meeting said it was really, really important to ensure there are really good pedestrian and cycle links back into the town wherever possible.

title: north-berwick-institution-sula-ii-is-retired
story: The Sula II, a much-loved wooden passenger boat, has ceased her summer tours around the Bass Rock and neighbouring islands after more than four decades of sailings.The clinker-built vessel is making her way to Southampton after being sold by owner Duncan MacRae.Mr MacRae, who purchased the vessel about  months ago, said: ldquoThe Sula II is a very old vessel and will struggle to comply with new safety regulations coming into force next year from the MCA .ldquoAs I take safety very seriously, I had the chance to sell the Sula II and she has now moved down to Southampton.ldquoSula III has now been ordered and purpose-built in Scotland to the highest modern standards and will be operational by next Easter.ldquoFor this season I am just about to secure the use of another vessel to keep the excellent Bass Rock sailings available for the public.The boat was originally purchased in the s by legendary North Berwick boatman and fisherman Fred Marr, who had been working on passenger launches from North Berwick throughout the s and s.She was the second boat he had bought for the purpose of tours, the first onebeing slightly old with a paraffin engine, so it was sold and Sula II replaced it.Pat Macaulay, Fredrsquos daughter, said: ldquoMy father purchased Sula II in  after seeing an advert in the Fishing News. This boat was originally called the Janet and was built in Norfolk.ldquoThe name Sula was chosen because it is the Latin name for the gannet, the bird that made Bass Rock a world-renowned bird sanctuary.The boat took tourists and locals out to sea from North Berwick on the Bass Rock tours under the Marr family up until , when Fredrsquos son Chris retired after  yearsrsquo sailing.Fred himself had retired in . He passed away in  and there is a plaque in his memory at North Berwick harbour.Sula II has seen many celebrities and dignitaries over her years, including Prince Charles, Brigitte Bardot, Sir David Attenborough, Alan Titchmarsh and Bill McLaren.Pat, who now lives on the Isle of Lewis, said: ldquoI have been contemplating for some time putting together a scrapbook of memories, photos, thoughts and reminisces from the many hundreds of people who enjoyed boat trips aboard Sula II over the years.ldquoSula II is etched into my heart and bloodstream, as is Bass Rock, itrsquos a very special place.To get in touch with Pat with memories from the Sula II, email patandthesula@gmail

title: long-serving-nursery-nurse-praised-as-she-retires
story: Susan Walker stepped down from her role at Macmerry Primary School shortly before the schools broke up for the Easter break.Jenner Welsh, who works at the school, said: ldquoSusan is known for her love of children, patience, organisation, kind manner and her commitment to the children and their families.ldquoShe has seen many colleagues come and go within the school and nursery and made many special friends along the way.ldquoSusan leaves us to embark on some travel, spend time with her family and take time to enjoy her many hobbies.ldquoShe will also be the newest member of the lsquoladies who lunch clubrsquo made from previous Macmerry retired staff.ldquoWe all wish her a well-deserved, long and enjoyable retirement.Susan lives to the east of Haddington with her husband.

title: drive-thru-coffee-shop-at-gateside-thought-to-be-starbucks-approved
story: Plans for a drive-thru coffee shop at Gateside West were given the go-ahead by East Lothian Council last week.The plans were lodged by Euro Garages Ltd, which is also behind the plans to transform the former Raceland karting centre, near Gladsmuir, into a roadside services hub.Starbucks are not named as applicants but within documents included in the Haddington planning application is a drawing labelled as lsquoStarbucks sitersquo.A spokeswoman for the coffee shop giants was tight-lipped as to whether they had any involvement with the proposals.She told the Courier: ldquoIrsquom afraid we arenrsquot able to comment on planning applications at this point in time.Plans for the coffee shop ndash which would be open seven days a week, from am to pm, and employ about  members of staff ndash were discussed by the townrsquos community council last month.They raised concerns about the noise generated by vehicles visiting the business.East Lothian Council has now given planning permission with a condition stating that an ldquoacoustic barrier has to be created between the boundary of the site and neighbouring houses.Jan Wilson, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, was hopeful the development would not impact upon similar businesses in the town centre.She said: ldquoIt might get more passing trade or trade from people who live up there [but]I would not specically go up there for a cup of coffee.There will be parking for  vehicles, including two disabled bays, as well as an electrical charging unit and spaces for bicycles.While drawings included in the application show more than  seats inside the shop.The plans were discussed by Haddington Business Community Partnership , which met last Tuesday.David Diggory, a member of HBCP who has run Diggoryrsquos Coffee Shop on Haddington High Street for nearly seven years, was confident that the introduction of another coffee shop-type business would not have a detrimental impact on his own business.He said: ldquoMy opinions obviously donrsquot necessarily reflect the whole of the group but I do kind of feel it is more competition for the likes of Costa Coffee [which has a cafe in the townrsquos Tesco] than myself.ldquoThere have been many places opened up in and around High Street and people still find us.ldquoPeople that want to shop local and support local businesses will continue to do so.Originally, the site was identied for a pub restaurant as part of a wider plan for  houses and industrial units.However, developers failed to find anyone interested in the section of land earmarked for a pub restaurant and instead applied for permission for  houses to be built on the .-hectare site.East Lothian Council refused that planning permission  months ago before an appeal was dismissed by the councilrsquos local review body, which stressed the councilrsquos commitment to the land being used for employment.

title: port-seton-woman-receives-maundy-purse-from-the-queen
story: Dorothy Tervit was presented the purse of specially minted coins by Her Majesty The Queen at a ceremony before Easter weekend.Dorothy, from Laburnum Avenue, told the Courier: ldquoWhen the invitation came through in November, I thought it was a hoax!ldquoI thought lsquowhy on earth would Buckingham Palace be writing to me rsquoThe -year-old, who is a member of the local community choir, the local history society and Chalmers Memorial Church, was nominated by an anonymous supporter.The nominator has to be a Christian minister and the recipient is not allowed to know their identity, though Dorothy has some ideas.She said: ldquoUsing the process of elimination, I could make an educated guess.ldquoIrsquom so grateful, though, as the whole experience was absolutely wonderful ndash a real once-in-a-letime moment.The Royal Maundy refers to the service where the British Monarch distributes small purses full of coins called Maundy money as symbolic alms to the nominated recipients. It is a ceremony thought to date back to the Middle Ages and took place at St Georgersquos Chapel in Windsor.The coins are presented in two leather purses, a white one containing coins to the value of the same number of pence as the years of the monarchrsquos age, and a red purse containing a pound and a p coin.Dorothy was one of  recipients. As the Queen is  years old, there are  female recipients and  male recipients, as well as  pence worth of special silver coins in one of the purses.The other purse presented included a commemorative pound coin marking the th anniversary of Queen Victoriarsquos birth.Dorothy attended the ceremony last week with her husband Tom.She added: ldquoThe Queen was so gracious, I felt undeserving. We werenrsquot allowed to speak to her, as per the rules, but she had such a warm smile for everyone in line for the purse.

title: cinema-planned-along-with-holiday-lodges-at-archerfield
story: Caledonian Heritable is keen to further develop Archerfield via a dozen two-bedroom cabins, as well as extending Fletcherrsquos Cottage Spa and creating a cinema and additional conference facilities. If approved, two new homes would also be built on the sitersquos eastern boundary, near Dirleton.A supporting statement included in a planning application to East Lothian Council said: ldquoThe Bank of Scotland has been funding the previous expansion of Archerfield and in addition we have been contributing part of the monies raised from selling the [housing] plots at Archerfield.ldquoIt has been quite challenging financing Archerfield up to this point and it has been most beneficial that the [housing] plots at Kings Cairn are now managing to pay back some of the financial support given to us by the Bank of Scotland. To enable the proposed increase in the number of hotel bedrooms [cabins], extensions to the spa and laundry facilities etc, we need to give the bank further comfort to continue supporting our ambition to build Archerfield into Scotlandrsquos premier hotel accommodation with a top-of-the-range spa, golf courses, conference facilities, cinema etc.ldquoThe bank has security over all the property and land at Archerfield but we now need them to extend our facility to allow us to finance the poundm projected costs.If given the green light, the project would also result in further jobs being created with  per cent more staff in line to be employed.Tom Drysdale, who lives in nearby Dirleton, is chairman of Gullane Area Community Council. He said there were concerns about the proposals, particularly regarding the two properties off Manse Road.Mr Drysdale said: ldquoDirleton Village Association has a very strong view on the matter and is supported by the community council.ldquoThis is part of a much bigger planning application, which involves new additional facilities in the Archerfield Links golfing estate, a signicant number of holiday lodges and aroom.ldquoThe community is not concerned about any of these items, other than two house lodges, right beside the village green in Dirleton. There is a very strong feel that this is completely inappropriate.ldquoThe proposal is to build two big two-storey houses, which would simply not fit into the village environment.Set in  acres, the Archerfield Estate is home to two golf courses and a iety of accommodation styles to rent, including grade one-listed Archerfield House.There is also a cafe, deli, food market, gt shop, bar and microbrewery at Archerfield Walled Garden.

title: tims-tales-wallaces-mutton-hole
story: AT THE tail end of the Easter weekend, I headed for Yellow Craig ndash not the beach, but the craggy small hill which gives the area its name.Itrsquos a volcanic vent, created millions of years ago, just like North Berwick Law nearby.But it canrsquot be compared to the Law. Itrsquos a tiny hill, and many people walk past without noticing it, as nature has covered much of it under a blanket of overgrowth.But close up Irsquove always thought it appears mysterious. It is made up of agglomerate, which is the remains of volcanic ash all mixed up with bits of other rock and stone, then solidied and compressed over millions of years.But in places the agglomerate rock looks like it could be the ancient rubble built walls of an old ruined castle. Steps now lead to the summit, and despite the smallness of the hill, the view from the top is quite spectacular.I could see Fidra Island basking in a shimmering sea when I climbed it in the evening of Easter Monday. I reflected that Robert Louis Stevenson must have once stood on this exact spot as he viewed what many say was his inspiration for Treasure Island.But my purpose that beautul evening was to find lsquoWallacersquos Mutton Holersquo. There was a local tradition that a small cave-like cavity on the north side of Yellow Craig bore this name, and although the origin of the tradition is lost, it was clearly linked to William Wallace.I found reference to this tradition in an old account from over  years ago in the Haddingtonshire Advertiser by a Mr Jamieson. However, it was brought to my mind when I read of the refurbishment of the Wallace Monument. As part of this, there will be the Luumlbeck letter on display, written by Wallace and sent to the merchants of Luumlbeck in .Wallace, it seems, was in East Lothian at the time this letter was composed. And it was this connection that sparked my memory of the reference to lsquoWallacersquos Mutton Holersquo on Yellow Craig and set me on my quest.But it was in the dying embers of the day we arrived, and I had limited time to explore. The kids had fallen asleep in the car and I think my long-suffering we was content to relax while I scrambled around a rock at the tail end of a fun but exhausting day.As I headed through the wood alone to the craig, the sun was already beginning to lower its head. The sound of birdsong was a crescendo naturersquos melody for spring.Yellow Craig wood isnrsquot ancient, most trees are around  years old. But there are some, mostly sycamores, which are clearly much older. They have exotic shapes and their twisted limbs and scaled bark make them look like fossilised dragons. Perhaps they are. There is one which grows close to the play park that even looks like a serpent.These older trees give this wood an ancient feel. There are also Scots pines, mostly along the edge of the wood. They are descendants of the great Caledonian Forest which once covered most of the north of Scotland. Patches of emigrant Scots pine can be found all over East Lothian and at Yellow Craig they seem to guard the wood from northerly gales, and they are bent and shaped by the wind.Scots pines also stand guard at Yellow Craig itself. When I arrived I didnrsquot initially head up the steps but scrambled up the northern slope, looking for Wallacersquos Mutton Hole.The meaning of this term is a subject of debate, and I claim no academic authority, but I wonderit could come from the term lsquomootrsquo, which is an old Anglo-Saxon word meaning debate or discussion. A moot hall was a room for this purpose in a medieval building, but Wallace was a guerilla fighter, so could this meeting place have been his moot ha If this was so, perhaps Yellow Craig was a meeting place, where Wallace and his followers once met to discuss strategy. Could the idea of the letter to Luumlbeck have been decided here, as they cast their eyes across the sea from the vantage of the rock Itrsquos an interesting idea, but of course therersquos no historical evidence for it. Yet most of what actually happened in those times has no historical evidence.I couldnrsquot find the hole or hollow, as nature has claimed the slope and thick vegetation meant I was kept away from the recesses hidden behind. Perhaps winter would have been a better time to search.But I was not disappointed. I sat on the summit and my instinct told me there was a mystery here that remains untold. A scant and seemingly forgotten oral tradition is not much to go on. But often an ancient half-whispered tradition has grown from a seed of truth.There is a similar East Lothian connection to Wallace in the Garleton Hills. I have written of the Wallace Cave there and the traditions associated with it. There is enough connection to our national hero in East Lothian to say our landscape can also claim connection to him.I will search deeper for references to Wallacersquos Mutton Hole at Yellow Craig andmy findings to this pagemy search proves fruitful. But regardless of the results of this search, for me Yellow Craig will always be a place of magic contemplation and imaginative possibilities.

title: worlds-oldest-golf-scorecard-from-musselburgh-up-for-auction
story: Estimated at pound,-,, the card, which has been framed and mounted, dates from December , .It shows that a Mr Cundell played the five holes within the Musselburgh race track twice, a total of  holes in  strokes. Charmingly, the golfer provided his own commentary in a handwritten note at the bottom of the card: ldquoDreadful storm of wind and rain ndash atmosphere quite yellow ndash just like the lurid regions of Pandemonium.Mr Cundell is almost certainly James Cundell, who was closely involved with the Thistle Golf Club since its founding in  and who published one of the first ever rule books of golf in .Kevin McGimpsey, Bonhamsrsquo golfing memorabilia consultant, said: ldquoThis original scorecard is in remarkable condition considering its age and the atrocious weather conditions at the time Mr Cundell played his round.ldquoIt has an excellent provenance, having once belonged to the well-known golfer Sir Henry Cotton, who kept it in his renowned Black Tin Box with other rare examples of historical golfing memorabilia.ldquoThe scorecard predates the oldest cards owned by the international golf museums.The scorecard will be auctioned at Bonhamsrsquo next sporting sale at its  Queen Street saleroom on Wednesday, which will present Part II of The Pierre Horwitz Collection of golfing memorabilia. This covers the period from the early part of the th century to the s and concentrates especially on the manufacture of clubs and balls and rare patented designs of both.Other highlights include: a white painted feather golf ball, handmade in about  by Allan Robertson, one of the most gted of the early professional golfers and a long nosed scared neck putter from about - made by Robert Forgan. The Pierre Horwitz collection Part I made a total of pound, last October.Documentary evidence proves that golf was played on Musselburgh Links as early as  although Mary, Queen of Scots reputedly played there in .

title: 110000-boost-for-musselburgh-charitys-work
story: The funding to the Bridges Centre, awarded over three years, will go towards the salary costs of a full-time personal development worker to deliver a programme of inidual and small group support to --year-olds.This will help young people develop their skills and aspirations for the future as the service seeks to build their emotional resilience and help them create positive relationships, enabling them to achieve their full potential.The grant, which was allocated through Children in Needrsquos Main Grants Programme, is its first funding allocation of the year, with additional cash-aid being distributed to projects across the UK throughout .Jim Boyle, chief executive of the Bridges Project, which is based on Musselburghrsquos Bogpark Road, said: ldquoWersquove been receiving funding from BBC Children in Need now for the last  years and, in that time, have been able to make a dference to hundreds of young peoplersquos lives.ldquoWersquore delighted that wersquoll be able to continue this for another three years in collaboration with our partners in education, social work, health and the voluntary sector.Florence Burke, national head of Scotland at BBC Children in Need, said: ldquoWe are delighted to fund the work of the Bridges Project and look forward to seeing the dference that this grant will make to children and young people across the region.Simon Antrobus, BBC Children in Needrsquos chief executive, added: ldquoAs always, thanks must go to our generous supporters and fundraisers. We are only able to make these much-needed awards because of them.In East Lothian and Midlothian, BBC Children in Need is currently funding nine projects to a value of pound,.Across Scotland, it has more than pound. million invested in projects making a positive dference to the lives of disadvantaged young people.For information on how to apply for funding, visit bbc pudsey grants

title: young-county-ballet-prodigy-gets-tuition-from-dance-star
story: Maisie Belle Black was trained for the day in Edinburgh by Danish dancer, choreographer and director Peter Schaufuss.The -year-old started learning at Dunbar School of Dance at the age of three and now trains with Scottish Ballet and the Edinburgh Ballet.She said: ldquoI love dancing. It gives me the freedom to express myself and I particularly enjoy the technical precision of ballet.ldquoI currently train several times a week but am always looking for more opportunities to dance and perform.Maisie, a student at Mary Erskine School, has already competed in many competitions including the Dance World Cup and Thatrsquos Showbiz.She had attended workshops at Edinburgh Festival Ballet School last year and jumped at the chance to work with the world-famous ballet dancer.She added: ldquoIrsquod heard a lot about Peter Schaufuss and his son Luke before as they are both very well-known.ldquoGetting to work with Peter was an amazing opportunity and I really enjoyed it.The famous dancer Schaufuss has performed and directed all over the world with leading companies including Kirov Ballet, Paris Opera Ballet, Royal Ballet and New York City Ballet, as well as founding The English National Ballet School.He said: ldquoThe masterclass presents an opportunity for Scottish dancers to spend a day learning from those that have been at the highest level of the dance profession.ldquoItrsquos an opportunity for students to be taught by some of the leading figures from the dance world and to learn what it takes to be a professional dancer.The class itself was designed by Schaufuss, who has plans to have a full-time school up and running from September based at St Stephenrsquos Church in Stockbridge, Edinburgh.Maisie added: ldquoMy ultimate dream is to be a professional dancer and perform every day.

title: magazine-aims-to-entice-new-haddington-residents-into-town-centre
story: Businesses in the town centre have joined forces to work on a magazine entitled lsquoMy Haddingtonrsquo.Moira Graham, of Haddington Business Community Partnership , said: ldquoWe are proposing to put together a one-off glossy magazine. We are going to run , copies aimed at the new housing.ldquoWith lots of local community members, our community groups are going to write their own editorials and tell us a little about what happens in Haddington.Members of HBCP, including award-winning Blooming Haddington, Friends of the River Tyne and ious sports groups, have been asked to contribute to the magazine, which will be A size.Mrs Graham added: ldquoAll the groups are going to have a wee say in it.ldquoA lot of people know what a great place Haddington is to live and work.ldquoWe are aiming to publish in the summer.Work is already under way to build more than  new homes at Letham Mains, between Haddingtonrsquos West Road and Pencaitland Road.Similarly, more than  new homes are being built at Dovecot, to the south of Pencaitland Road.Business representatives have repeatedly stressed the importance of attracting new residents into the centre to boost the local economy.The proposed magazine was highlighted at Haddingtonrsquos community council meeting and received the backing of long-standing chairwoman Jan Wilson.She described Haddington as ldquoa beautul town, steeped in history.Mrs Wilson said: ldquoLet us hope it will bring people into the town to use the town centre.ldquoIf this magazine can bring people together and make them aware of the things going on in the town it has to be a good thing.

title: disruption-expected-during-four-months-of-pipeline-work-near-morham
story: Five kilometres of pipeline will run from Cockles Brae, south of Haddington, to the Morham crossroads.The new pipe will, says Scottish Water, improve the reliability and resilience of the water supply network for customers in the local area and the wider network.The pipe will run through fields, a burn and across roads, replacing an old nine-inch steel pipe which has come to the end of its le.The work sees Scottish Water Alliance partner Caledonia Water Alliance in stripping soil from the route before cutting a trench for the new pipeline.During the work, which is expected to take about four months, there will be some short periods of local road closures and residents in these areas will be kept informed, says Scottish Water.Scottish Waterrsquos Scott Fraser said: ldquoThis new pipeline will ensure that customers can continue to enjoy a reliable supply of clear, fresh drinking water.

title: rocket-firm-hopes-to-test-engines-at-former-power-station-site
story: Skyrora has revealed it has identied part of the old Cockenzie Power Station site as a location for its test site.The company, which describes itself as a launch vehicle development company with aims to cater for the growing demand to send small satellites into space, is expected to apply for planning permission from East Lothian Council within the next few months.It held a public consultation on its proposals at the Port Seton Centre today .The Courier revealed last August that Skyrora were looking at East Lothian sites, with the former power station one of the possibilities it was considering to test its rocket engines.Skyrora said that the engine testing would not involve the launching of rockets from the site but would require fuel to be stored on-site to fire up the engines.The UK Space Agency announced that it was investing millions of pounds in a site in Sutherland as the new home of the UKrsquos first spaceport for launching rockets.Skyrora said it was looking for an engine test site within an hour of its Edinburgh offices to give it a local base.It said it had identied part of the former power station site, which was bought by East Lothian Council last year, for its tests.The area being put forward for the site is part of the old coal store.Skyrora said: ldquoThe site will be protected, and special measures will be undertaken to control down the noise impacts to acceptable levels and minimal-period test events.Last year it was revealed that Glasgow produced more space satellites than any other city outside of the USA.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoWe have been in discussions with Skyrora about the possibility of a temporary lease of land for activities based around engine testing.ldquoA planning application would need to be submitted by Skyrora and considered in due course.

title: dominos-pizza-set-to-come-to-tranent
story: Work has begun to transform the former Indian takeaway at  Bridge Street into a new business, which the Courier understands will be a Dominorsquos.Although a spokesperson from Dominorsquos Pizza declined to comment on whether it was opening in Tranent, signage already approved by East Lothian Council for the premises shows the Dominorsquos name and logo.Tranent is set to become the second town in East Lothian to become home to a Dominorsquos ndash the companyrsquos only other East Lothian outlet currently is on Musselburghrsquos North High Street.

title: dog-walkers-surprise-at-coming-across-octopus-on-beach-at-musselburgh
story: Shona Grieve, , from Longniddry, who now lives in the Fisherrow area, was taking her two-year-old white German shepherd Ivy for her regular walk on the beach when she saw the dead creature.She said: "I was walking at the Fisherrow end of the beach beside the the bowling green."I had thrown Ivys ball and walked to where the ball landed and saw the octopus."I walk the beach every day, sometimes three times a day, with Ivy. In all the years of living by the sea, I have never seen an octopus before. So for me it was a very unusual find. Ivy was a bit curious of it too but more interested in her ball to be fair."She added: "I kept ing to it, to convince myself it was dead which it definitely was."The sea was far out but to reassure myself I managed to put it in a pool of water. This was early on and there was nobody  about to show so I took a picture."I have since been told it is getting more common to find them. I had never seen one before ndash my only rare sighting on the beach was when I was a child and found a small pool of seahorses."An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: "The lesser octopus is not that common but they do turn up occasionally, cast up especially after a storm or following prolonged rough weather."Live specimens have also been found in rock pools at the lowest part of the beach."

title: scotland-footballer-leigh-griffiths-appears-at-speeding-trial
story: Footballer Grfiths, who lives in Wallyford, is alleged to have been caught behind the wheel of his red Range Rover Sport driving at mph while in a mph zone.The -year-old Scotland international is alleged to have been clocked speeding on the A between the Burnshot Flyover and Cammo Road, Edinburgh, on January  last year.On day two of the trial, Edinburgh Justice of the Peace Court heard that the registered keeper of the vehicle at the time of the alleged speeding offence was Nathan Redmond, of Bournemouth.Mr Redmond was contacted by Police Scotland and he informed officers that the driver at the time was former Hibs striker Grfiths.Grfiths was then written to, informing him of the intended prosecution, but he failed to reply.The striker was then written to again by police staff in March last year and eventually replied stating that he had been behind the wheel at the time of the alleged driving offence.A fixed penalty of a pound fine and three penalty points was then offered to Grfiths but was refused.Justice Hillary Stevenson heard from Robert Jefferson, the operator of the mobile camera unit who allegedly caught the footballer speeding, that he had carried out all the necessary and required checks on the equipment.Mr Jefferson, , said that he was ldquosatisfied the camera equipment was ldquotype-approved and the device had been in complete working order that day.Mr Jefferson added that the speed gun used to catch speeding motorists that day was ldquoincredibly accurate and Police Scotland had ldquocomplete confidence in them.The part-heard trial was adjourned for a second time due to witnesses not being cited by the Crown following confusion concerning evidence that had previously been agreed between the prosecution and the footballerrsquos defence team.The footballer was seen joking with court staff prior to his case calling and signed autographs.Grfiths continues to deny driving at mph in a mph limit between the Burnshot Flyover and Cammo Road in Edinburgh on January , .The trial will continue on May .

title: pop-up-bar-plan-at-closed-hotel-in-north-berwick
story: Advertisements have been placed in the windows of the former County Hotel on North Berwick High Street highlighting plans for a new short-term venture called lsquoBeach Hutrsquo.The former -bedroom hotel and bar has been closed for more than six months following the departure of previous licensee Tony Breathnach.The brightly coloured adverts say the venue is looking for full and part-time chefs, managers and waiting staff.A spokeswoman for building owners Star Pubs  Bars said: ldquoWe are keen to reopen The County Hotel as soon as possible.ldquoWe have an experienced and highly talented operator who is interested in launching an exciting pop-up bar and restaurant at the pub in time for the summer.ldquoAs soon as the plans and timings are finalised, we will be able to share more information.Last month, the Courier told how Star Pubs  Bars, part of Heineken UK, had longer-term plans for the premises, which included a major refurbishment.If proposals submitted to East Lothian Council are approved, changes would be made inside the building, with the bar server and public toilets relocated. Outside, a single-storey outbuilding would also be given a new lease of le to form an additional enclosed bar area which would serve food.The company spokesman added: ldquoWe have a long-term vision for The County Hotel and we are developing plans for a major investment programme to create a fresh and exciting pub.ldquoWe are looking for a new licensee to work with us on this great venture. In the meantime, The County Hotel will be reopened with temporary managers in place.Judy Lockhart, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, said: ldquoThe community council is pleased to note that a pop-up restaurant bar will be opening shortly in The County. High streets are having a tough time at the moment and the community council are thrilled to see initiatives such as pop-up businesses being utilised to prevent units lying empty.We hope that a permanent business can be installed for the longer term however, for the time being, this is fantastic news.

title: honest-lad-and-honest-lass-2019-elected
story: A large crowd, including representatives from the Border towns, gathered to hear the election announcement, which was made from the outside balcony at The Brunton at about pm on Friday.The new Honest Lad and Honest Lass were presented with their medals of office by this yearrsquos sasher PC Dougie Smith, youth community officer.The announcement followed a public election earlier in the day, prior to which the only other candidate for Honest Lad, Michael Morrison, was disbarred from standing due to a pending court case for allegedly using a car without insurance.Aidan, , and Claire, , who was an attendant last year, made their way to an open carriage and, along with the attendant for  Abbie Thomson,  ndash who had stood as an Honest Lass candidate ndash they were piped through the town by the Boysrsquo Brigade Pipe Band. Volunteers from Musselburgh Sea Cadets had the honour of pulling the carriage.The official party then made its way to Musselburgh Rugby Club to join well-wishers. In keeping with tradition, they danced an eightsome reel with support from th anniversary Attendants Carol Colville and David Banks, and Past Attendant Kier Robinson.Aidan was a pupil at Loretto RC Primary School in Musselburgh before attending St Davidrsquos High School in Dalkeith. On leaving school, he was appointed as an apprentice with Slight Joinery Ltd.Claire was born and brought up in Whitecraig, attending Whitecraig Primary and Musselburgh Grammar Schools. She works at Pinkie Farm Shop as a general assistant and has been a member of Musselburgh Crusaders Riding Club since she was  years old.Abbie, who attended Campie Primary School and Musselburgh Grammar School, is currently in her final year studying BScApplied Animal Science at Scotlandrsquos Rural University College and she is due to graduate in July.They will lead the Musselburgh Festival which runs from July  to  with a range of events for all the family on offer as well as traditional favourites such as the sashing of the Honest Lad and Lass, and ever-popular Crusaders Chase.Stefanie Talac, secretary of the Honest Tounrsquos Association, said: ldquoNow that the election has been run and our official party is in place, the committee will be focussing on festival week itself."We have a few changes to the week following feedback in . This year will see the kirkin move back to am in St Michaelrsquos with the sashing taking place at approximately .pm at the Mall.ldquoOur Family Fun Day will now be on Saturday, July , in Pinkie St Peterrsquos playing fields. This event was a huge success last year and we wish to build on that. Lewisvale proved to be constrictive in size and, due to the vast number of families who attended, we felt that a bigger space was necessary for safety.She added: ldquoThe Saturday is also festival day which we wish to make a focus for the townrsquos celebrations. The treasure hunt which has previously taken place on the Monday will now take place on the Wednesday morning.ldquoThese moves look to ensure that we still have family friendly events spread over the week and allow the official party to attend these as well as the ious visits to nurseries, care homes and local businesses throughout the week."Festival week will run from Saturday, July , until Sunday, July , with a wide iety of events to hopefully suit everyone.

title: ready-for-this-years-walk-with-scott-this-weekend
story: The Walk With Scott Foundation is holding its seventh annual walk around East Lothian, raising funds for local causes.The foundation was formed by Tranent man Scott Glynn, who decided just under seven years ago to celebrate his th birthday by walking to the six rugby clubs in the county and putting a collection tin in the bars in each club, before sharing the donations between ious local groups and causes.The walks have been going on every year ever since, with more and more people getting involved ndash and, incredibly, the charity has now raised more than pound, over the years.More than  people will be walking this year, with the route starting at Cockenzie and Port Seton Royal British Legion, heading along to Musselburgh then down the banks of the Esk to Whitecraig, along the old Pencaitland railway, on to Boggs Holdings, up through Butterdean Woods, along the Longniddry railway line to Longniddry, then back along the coast road to Cockenzie, a total of about  miles.A donation page has been set up to help the fundraising effort, and so far the foundation has smashed its pound, target, with more than pound, raised and rising.Scott, , told the Courier: ldquoItrsquos amazing, and we still have time before and after the walk to raise more.ldquoWe have no plans for the money at present ndash itrsquos good to just have some there sosomething comes up, we can use it.The foundation previously has been able to jump into action quickly when helping out East Lothian Foodbank and handing over pound, to the Hollies Day Centre in Musselburgh after it suffered a break-in and theft of its safe.On support for the charity, Scott added: ldquoI think itrsquos because we support local causes and people can see the dference that we make. Now wersquove been around for a while, people know us and know what wersquore about.Scott suffered a health scare two years ago when he was diagnosed with liver cancer and underwent le-saving surgery when he was given a liver transplant.He said: ldquoIrsquom feeling really good and am absolutely ready to go.ldquoI enjoy the walks and am feeling fit and ready. Irsquove been training, as have everyone . Itrsquos great seeing the videos and updates that people send through of them training and working hard.To donate to the charityrsquos efforts visit uk.virginmoneygiving WWSFWalk ndash more information is available from the Walk with Scott Facebook page.

title: talented-amateur-golfer-bob-walkingshaw-remembered
story: Robert lsquoBobrsquo Walkingshaw passed away peacefully at Haddington Care Home last Wednesday after a long illness.Born in Old Craighall, he moved to Salters Road, Wallyford, at the age of  with his father Bob, mother Isa, brother Ian and sisters Elizabeth and Janet.A former pupil of Musselburgh Grammar School, he worked in the ropery at the former Brunton Wire Works in Musselburgh.Mr Walkingshaw took up golf at the age of six.He honed his skills on the fairways of Musselburgh Golf Club, becoming a scratch golfer. He also went on to become a member of Royal Musselburgh Golf Club and Musselburgh Links, The Old Course.In , Mr Walkingshaw, a former Lothians County player, won all four Musselburgh championships: the Monktonhall closed club event Musselburgh Open on the same course Royal Musselburgh Connaught Cup and championship at the Old Links at the racecourse.He also lted the Scottish seniors title twice at amateur level.His sporting prowess did not stop at golf and he became a semi-professional footballer for Stenhousemuir FC. His football career was cut short when he suffered a dislocated hip resulting from a tackle on the pitch and spent six weeks in hospital.A member of Wallyford Bowling Club, he also enjoyed played at the indoor bowling club at Meadowmill.Mr Walkingshaw cared for his mother at their family home on Salters Road.His sister Elizabeth said that he was known as a local ldquolegend in golfing circles, where he was popular and well respected. He was renowned for being ldquoa true gentleman on and off the course.ldquoHe quietly lived his le, she added.Mr Walkingshaw was married twice and has two daughters, Kristi and Debbie, by his second marriage.A devoted grandfather-of-four, he will be sadly missed by the family, including his brother and two sisters.A funeral service takes place tomorrowat Seafield Crematorium at pm. All are welcome to attend.

title: report-of-hare-coursing-near-humbie
