title: Strictly dancing at Newcastle school
story: A NEWCASTLE primary school are to host a Strictly Come Dancing fundraiser to help raise money for the school.St Maryrsquos Primary School will be staging the night at Slieve Donard Resort and Spa next Saturday, May .Q Radiorsquos Ryan A promises to bring a pinch of razzmatazz to the dance extravaganza as hersquoll be acting as compere for the evening.Dancers include teachers, classroom assistants, parents and past pupils. There will be two fabulous dance demonstrations from European Argentina Tango champions, Anna Arriza DrsquoEste and Marco de Camillis, and  Irish dancing world champions Orlaith Bradley and David Carberry.Jenni Maguire, a teacher at the school, has been putting the dancers through their paces along with former All-Ireland Ballroom champion and choreographer Graham Jack.The event promises to be a great night of entertainment, says Graham,with demonstrations from the world champion Irish dancers to kick start the night followed by couples taking to the stage with a selection of Latin and ballroom dances.He said: ldquoI am really excited about our event. It is a great opportunity to bring the school and community together for what promises to be a real dance spectacular, while raising money for our school.ldquoI couldnrsquot do what these dancers have done. They deserve great credit for putting two dance routines together in such a short period of time.ldquoThe contestants seem to have enjoyed the build up. While there has been pressure due to the time scale in preparation and the work load involved, there have been no tears or tantrums.He added. ldquoThe practices have been good fun. There have been plenty of laughs. The iniduals and couples mix well and we all get on the best. But when the hard work needs to be done, they take it very seriously.Jenni said the couples have put in many hours of rehearsals, given freely of their time and have shown great dedication.She said: ldquoSome have revealed much hidden talent in rehearsals and head judge, UTVrsquos Rita Fitzgerald, will have a tough job on her hands but with the help of the  and votes by the audience on the night the Strictly Ball could be a closely fought battle.One of the contestants, Claire Toner, whose son Dylan is a P pupil at the school, said: ldquoI volunteered as I wanted to do something dferent. It was a case of challenging myself and trying something fun and exciting.One person who has taken it all in her stride is classroom assistant Rachel Lowey. A past pupil of the school, she is paired with another former pupil and friend Shane Kearney.She said: ldquoLike Claire, I wanted to learn something new. Never in a million years did I think Irsquod be dancing on the same stage as some of my old teachers and classroom assistants.None of the dancers have experienced formal dance training before and for some it has been very dficult attending the twice weekly rehearsals.ldquoAs enjoyable as itrsquos been, one Strictly is my limit, said school principal Philip Fusco. ldquoWe hope this will be a superb event, not just for the school community of St Maryrsquos.ldquoWe look forward to welcoming everyone on the night and I have no doubt every guest will leave with a spring in their step.Tickets are available from the school office and are priced at pound for adult sand pound concession. You can also show your support and make a donation through JustGiving page.Many of the businesses, parents, friends and family have already shown their support by sponsoring a dancer. The school would like to express their heartfelt gratitude for their support.Sponsors include: McKeeverrsquos Chemist, Property Directions, ActiSport, Nutty Chef, Cocorsquos, Quinnrsquos, Diamond Patrsquos, Smallrsquos Body Repair and Paintworx, ADS Mechanical Ltd, DTS Plumbing and Heating, Mortgage and Insurance Directions, Mark Samuel Haulage, Kelly Brothers Building Contractors, Medicare, Donard Wines, Tap Room in the Donard Bar, Matthew Toner Electrics  Lick Gelato, Joe Quality Meats, Fitzpatrickrsquos Car and Commercial Repair, ADHD Parent Support Group, Shimna Cafe, Protamino Nutrition Ltd, Blue Beans and BodyRox..prettyPhoto

title: Vandals target playground days after opening
story: THOUGHTLESS vandals have been criticised for damaging play equipment at a recently refurbished play park at the Westlands estate in Crossgar.Community worker Paul Teggart and Rowallane councillors Terry Andrews and Patrick Brown are angry that literally within days of the new facility being opened the equipment was needlessly damaged.Mr Teggart, who worked hard to persuade Newry, Mourne and Down Council to upgrade a previously dilapidated play facility at the estate, said what happened had left him lost for words.ldquoThe new play facility was opened on Tuesday of last week an damaged just a matter of days later. This senseless vandalism has to stop and stop now, he declared.ldquoThe play equipment was specically designed for small children and it is my understanding that the names of people who were spotted in the vicinity of the playground when it was vandalised have been handed over to the authorities.Mr Teggart said Crossgar was a village proud of its mixed community with people getting on well together and working in unison to make it a welcoming and vibrant place.ldquoWe all get along with each other but it would appear that there are several youths who are determined to cause harm and have no respect for anyone or indeed young childrenrsquos play equipment, he continued.Mr Teggart added: ldquoWestlands residents are rightly upset with one suggesting to me that whoever was responsible should be made to pay for the damage they have caused.Cllr Andrews said this ldquowanton act of vandalism was totally out of order and uncalled for, emphasising that it was children who suffered as a result of the ldquodespicable action of others.ldquoI have made local council officials aware of what happened and and hope that the damaged equipment can be replaced. I was proud to see a play park which had been neglected for years rejuvenated, but the damage to the equipment is so disappointing.Cllr Andrews said he had many good memories of growing up in Westlands, explaining that after years of having nothing, it was ldquowonderful to see the play park rejuvenated for so many to enjoy.He continued: ldquoI hope those responsible will be apprehended. The message must go out that this kind of behaviour will not be tolerated.Cllr Andrews said many people worked hard to persuade the local council to redevelop the Westlands play park and are bitterly disappointed that their commitment and dedication to the local community is not shared by others.Cllr Brown said he was ldquoshocked to learn that play equipment had been damaged describing those responsible as ldquothoughtless vandals.He continued: ldquoAll councillors worked hard to deliver this upgraded play park for the community and to see it so needlessly damaged in the first week it has been open is so disappointing and adds to the ongoing anti-social behaviour problem in Crossgar.Cllr Brown said he met with Mr Teggart at the play park to inspect the damage and discuss how the local authority and PSNI can stop such ldquoreckless behaviour in the future.He added: ldquoThis sort of action cannot continue and those responsible will be held accountable..prettyPhoto

title: Voters take to the polls
story: VOTERS go to the polls across the district tomorrow to elect  councillors to Newry, Mourne and Down Council.Seventy one candidates are contesting the seats up for grabs in the Downpatrick, Rowallane, Slieve Croob, Mournes, Crotlieve, Slieve Gullion and Newry areas.With the final day of canvassing already underway and candidates targeting any remaining undecided voters, all eyes will be on the magical turnout number which could decide success or failure for some.Turnout in the  council election was just over % which saw almost , people visiting polling stations across the district.As the local council prepares for its second four year term, Sinn Fein and the SDLP will be battling to become the largest party and it is certainly all to play for.Both parties currently have  councillors with Sinn Fein sources quietly confident that the party will have increased its number of seats once the final result has been declared.What is clear is that the final outcome of tomorrowrsquos election is the toughest to call in decades given the number of interesting battles taking place right across the district.Locally, all eyes will be on Downpatrick, Rowallane, Slieve Croob and The Mournes which are intriguing to say the least, with the outcome potentially resulting in a dramatic change in the political landscape and some high profile figures losing out.In Downpatrick, attention will centre on the battle between Sinn Fein and the SDLP for electoral supremacy in an area where five seats are available.The SDLPrsquos Dermot Curran, Gareth Sharvin and John Trainor are out to retain their seats, with Sinn Fein aiming to ensure that Oonagh Hanlon and Jordan Madden will secure seats on the local authority for the first time.However, Independent councillor Cadogan Enright firmly intends to retain his seat, with strong support from a number of leading community groups in Downpatrick and Lecale.Add Aontuacute , the Green Party , Alliance , the DUPand UUPinto the mix and the expected dog fight for the fth seat could well be decided by transfers.In Rowallane, Independent candidate Martyn Todd and Sinn Feinrsquos Marianne Cleary will try to upset the current status quo in an area where the five seats are shared between the DUP, UUP, SDLP and Alliance.Sinn Fein has never held a seat in Rowallane before, but clinching one in a traditional unionist stronghold would represent a seismic sht.The SDLPrsquos Terry Andrews topped the Rowallane poll in , but was only  votes ahead of the UUPrsquos Robert Burgess, who is confident his running mate, Walter Lyons, who polled  first preference votes five years ago, can join him in the debating chamber.Lyons is the only Ballynahinch-based candidate contesting the poll, with DUP sources confident that Billy Walker and Harry Harvey will retain their seats. But with no TUV candidate, what will the  voters who backed Philip Hamilton in  do this time around Independent candidate Todd is expected to eat into sitting Alliance councillorrsquos Patrick Brownrsquos vote, with the Green Party intent on making an impression through Emma Cairns. Aontuacutersquos Liam Mulhern is contesting his first election and with  candidates chasing five seats the election count will be a particularly nervous affair.In Slieve Croob, the SDLP is keen to grab two of the five seats up for grabs with current encumbent Mark Murnin, the local councilrsquos current chairman, joined by party stalwart Hugh Gallagher.Sinn Fein has made its intention clear by fielding three candidates. Republicans currently hold two seats through Roacuteisiacuten Howell and John Rice and are aiming to ensure through the partyrsquos tried and trusted vote management system that Drumaness woman Cathy Mason will also secure a seat.Sitting DUP councillor Garth Craig is not seeking re-election with the party selecting Maynard Hanna to defend his seat, while Alan Lewis is flying the flag for the Ulster Unionists.Alliance currently hold a seat in Slieve Croob through Andy McMurray but he surprised many byopting to stand in the Mournes area, with his position being contested by university graduate Gregory Bain from Clough.The Mournes is another intriguing battleground where former South Down Ulster Unionist MLA Harold McKee is bidding to make ato local politics and the SDLP is aiming toits sitting councillors, Laura Devlin and Brian Quinn.However, Sinn Fein has an eye on one of the SDLP seats and is fielding three candidates, sitting councillors Willie Clarke and Sean Doran alongside Leanne McEvoy.Henry Reilly topped the poll in  while standing on a UKIP ticket. Now an Independent Unionist, he looks set to retain his seat alongside DUP stalwart Glyn Hanna, with all eyes on Alliancersquos Andrew McMurray following his switch from Slieve Croob..prettyPhoto

title: Zak tops Wicklow qualifiers
story: NEWCASTLE ACrsquos Zak Hanna has been selected to represent Ireland in the upcoming European Mountain Running Championships which take place in the scenic Swiss town of Zermatt, at the foot of the world famous Matterhorn Mountain.Living on the slopes of Slieve Croob outside Dromara, Zak travelled down to Wicklow on Saturday to compete in the trial race which would select the team to travel to Switzerland.With this yearrsquos race an uphill only race, compared to last yearrsquos championship being an lsquoup and downrsquo race, runners competing in the trial started at Crone Woods car park on the edge of the Wicklow Mountains and climb along the Wicklow Way trails before entering the open mountain and begin the long and steep ascent to the summit of Djouce Mountain at  mabove sea level-similar to running from Newcastle to the top of Slieve Commedagh.Zak summited Djouce in first place with a good gap over the second-placed runner to add another Irish cap to his list..prettyPhoto

title: ballinamallard supporters pulling out the stops for cup final
story: Trans-Atlantic trips, cancelled plane tickets, hopping back and forth across the Irish Sea. Just some of the trips and sacrices that are being made by Mallards supporters to ensure they are in Windosr Park for the biggest game in the clubrsquos history this Saturday.Kick off in the Irish Cup final is at .pm and the stands will be rocking with Mighty Duck supporters dreaming of the sweetest end to what has been an incredible journey.And speaking of journeys there are plenty being made this week. Former Ballinamallard manager Whitey Anderson boarded a plane in America, where he coaches soccer now, and has landed for the big day.ldquoIt is an occasion not to be missed for anyone involved in Ballinamallard, past or present. I always liked managing at Windsor, we actually beat Linfield three times in four years there. To win a cup final would just be unbelievable and a great reward for everyone at the club for all the hard work that goes on.Another Ballinamallard fan who is flying across water is Stephen Armstrong. He hasnrsquot got as far to travel as Whitey as he lives in England but a four hour car journey has to be made to Newcastle before making his flight.A family wedding for his we meant that Stephen was earmarked for baby sitting duties. But a clash with the Mallardsrsquo big day meant some creative thinking was needed, and he found it in the shape of fellow Ballinamallard supporter Scott Williams.Scott lives in Newcastle and his we has kindly agreed to take charge of the two Amrstrong kids, along with her own two kids, for the weekend while her husband and Stephen head across the Irish Sea.ldquoIt is very good of her to let us go off gallivanting for the weekend, Stephen explained, before adding.ldquoWe are due to stay in Belast on Saturday night butballinamallard win it will be hard to resist a trip down the road.Someone better tell Mrs Williams she could have the kids for an extra night!Football writer and UEFA Communications consultant, Laure James, fell in love with the Mallards while covering them the season they were promoted to the Premiership back in . For a lover of football history a chance to see the first Irish Cup final involving a Fermanagh team was something not to be missed with Marshall tweeting ldquoItrsquos going to be a quare day at Windsor!!Finally, one person very close to the squad has had to rebook flights for a wedding abroad. Mark McConkey, son of manager Harry, and a former player for Ballinamallard wasnrsquot going to miss the chance to see his dad manage a team in the Irish Cup final.ldquoIt is a once in a letime thing. title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast.Speaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and ten native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and chairman David Connolly said: Itrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.French judge Laurent Antignac was impressed with the professionalism of the young showmanship competitors.ldquoThey are a credit to Northern Ireland, he commented.ABERDEEN ANGUSA strong entry of Aberdeen Angus calves were judged by William McLaren from the noted Netherton Herd based at Blackford in Perthshire.Stealing the limelight in the junior section was the -month-old heer, Home Farm Ebony Stunner bred by Fintan Keown, Belleek. secured signicant victories in the count so far for the new Antrim and Newtownabbey Borough Council.In three out of the four seats being counted today, the party’s candidates have surged out in front of all others in terms of first-preference votes – in one case by an incredible margin.Alliances Neil Kelly pictured hugging a supporter in the Valley Leisure Centre on --, after securing a massive victory in Antrim.By contrast in , Alliance did not top a single one of the seven seats in the borough.In the Antrim sea, incumbent Alliance councillor Neil Kelly romped home at around midday, winning , first-preference votes.This is well over twice as many as the nearest candidate in the seat – the DUP’s John Smyth, who won .In , the seat had been won by the UUP’s Adrian Cochrane-Watson, with Alliance finishing fourth in the first-preference stakes .Elsewhere in the borough, the Glengormley Urgan seat was topped by Julian McGrath of the Alliance, winning , first-preference votes, compared with , for his nearest rival, the DUP’s Phillip Brett.And in Macedon, the top-rated candidate in terms of first-preference votes was Alliance’s Billy Webb, coming in with , votes .In addition, Julie Gilmour secured  first-preference votes in Threemilewater, meaning she too is likely to be elected once transfer votes are counted.David Ford, the former Alliance leader, told the News Letter the result was “quite an achievement”.It had become apparent even from the outset of counting that it would be a good day for Alliance, and he said: “It’s rare that I come to this building [the Valley Leisure Centre, where the count is always held] and am grinning from ear to ear at am.“We knew the four were all doing very well.”Elsewhere in the Province, even people who were little more than “paper candidates” were performing well for the party, he said.Early results indicate openly gay DUP candidate looks set to seize seatPolitical leaders cast votes as NI elects new councillors candidates, but also the foot soldiers who enthusiastically campaigned for the upstart party which would smash Northern Ireland’s political establishment.There were always criticisms from some in both church and party who saw the tension between a secular party with ambitions of winning votes and a fundamentalist church with the aim of saving souls.But those largely lay below the surface until Paisley’s decision to enter government with Sinn Fein, something which dismayed many in the church, who had been taught to view Sinn Fein in theological terms as the representatives of evil. The church gave Paisley an ultimatum: Choose to remain as moderator or remain as first minister. He opted for the latter and, after  years, was replaced as moderator.In his blistering valedictory interview with Eamonn Mallie in , Paisley said that his church critics “do not have the ear of God on this matter [power-sharing with Sinn Fein]”, a claim which appeared almost sacrilegious to some within the church. He also said that his family no longer entered his former church – although his son Kyle remains a Free Presbyterian cleric in England.Then in December  the church criticised the party for allowing retrospective pardons of those convicted of homosexual offences to pass through the Assembly. In implicit praise of the DUP’s nemesis, the church said that the proposal “was opposed only by Mr Allister of the TUV while sadly many others remained silent”. The church said it was “deeply grieved and bitterly disappointed” at the failure of MLAs to oppose the pardons.Now the uneasy relationship between a party which sees the strategic value in secularising and a church which believes that God’s law is unchangeable have ed with the DUP’s choice of Alison Bennington, a lesbian, as one of its council candidates. Ms Bennington has said she is standing “based on what I can deliver as a councillor ... not based on my sexual orientation”, and it is clear that the party leadership has endorsed what in any other party would be a fairly unremarkable stance.Ms Bennington was chosen centrally by the party, itself an indication that the party was taking a strategic decision to test the waters with its supporters. But for a party which once campaigned under the banner ‘Save Ulster from sodomy’ for homosexuality to remain a criminal offence, it is nevertheless a striking indication of how the DUP is changing.Traditionalist DUP MLA Jim Wells, who is currently suspended by the party, has been outspoken about what he described as a hint of “a major – and very worrying – change in the policy of the DUP on social issues”.On Saturday, TUV leader Jim Allister said he was struck in canvassing “by the number of lelong DUP voters dismayed by what they see as their party’s softening on the gay marriage issue because of the Bennington nomination”.Mr Wells yesterday said that “many, many DUP members up to the highest level”, including MPs, MLAs and former ministers, had been in contact with him to express concern about the issue because it was “a huge change in the ethos and tradition of the DUP”.Free Presbyterian sadness at the political normalisation of relations that contravene Scripture Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BELF | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BELF | Article Teaser"The South Down MLA said that there was concern within the party that it was “a step towards other radical change” and that people who had in some cases been members of the party for  years “simply cannot come to terms with this decision”.At the weekend, DUP veteran John Carson, posted on Facebook about the decision. The Ballymena councillor, who is standing for re-election on Thursday, said that he had been aDUP member for  years but “I say quite openly and with no fear of the consequences ‘NOT IN MY NAME’. I first entered politics because of my admiration for Dr Ian RK Paisley and ... I make no apologies to anyone for saying I am an old Paisleyite.”He went on: “I believe in the coming days not only myself but many of us will have some soul-searching to do and some tough decisions to make”. Invoking images of Old Testament idolatry, Mr Carson asked people to pray for wisdom for “those of us who have not bowed the knee to baal” as they “stand against evil in these days”.On Saturday, the presbytery officers of the Free Presbyterian Church issued a statement which was unusually oblique for a denomination known for its full-frontal assaults on those it regards as acting sinfully. The statement, a clear response to the DUP move, did not name the party but said that it “underlines its opposition to all marital and sexual relationships outside the covenant of Biblical marriage”.It added: “Therefore, as a church we are saddened by the attempts of political parties to normalise and promote marital and sexual relationships that are in contravention of the clear teaching of Scripture.”The statement was read out in some Free Presbyterian churches on Sunday, although not in others, in what may be a hint of the church – as well as the party – being split on the issue.Although a tiny denomination, Free Presbyterianism has long exerted an influence which exceeds its size, both through the DUP and its frequent pronouncements to the media about issues of public morals.One church source said that there was a desire among some within the congregation to see DUP party officers who are members of the church disciplined for their role in Ms Bennington’s selection.In response to the church’s statement, the DUP merely said: “Our position on support for traditional marriage is well known and as the party leader indicated last week, it has not changed.”An academic study, published as the book The Democratic Unionist Party: From Protest To Power, four years ago found that the Free Presbyterian Church continued to wield huge influence within the party, with % of DUP members being Free Presbyterian. That meant that Free Presbyterians were  times more common in the DUP than in the population.It has been clear for some time that the DUP is no longer “the DUP at prayer”. Credltspan classtruncate-full-screengtit: Patrick Olnerlt spangtlt spangtlt spangt" New Marie Curie cafe opens to publicDay therapy manager Sam Clements, clinical nurse specialist Alison Palmer, Nurseltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgt Manager CNS Donna Lltspan classtruncate-full-screengtee and lead nurse Carolyn Gent enjoy a cuppa. Credit: Patrick Olnerlt spangtlt spangtlt spangt" New Marie Curie cafe opens to publicMarie Curie staff and volunteers catch up at the cafeacute opening. Credit: Paltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgttrick Olnerlt spangtlt spangt" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentA TERMINAL illness charity is attempting to bust the myths of hospice, by opening its doors to the general public with a new cafeacute.The Marie Curie Cafeacute at the charityrsquos Cardf and the Vale Hospice in Penarth was officially opened by actress Suzanne Packer, who is soon to appear in series two of Keeping Faith.The Marie Curie Cafeacute, situated in the basement of the hospice, has opened its doors not only to staff, patients and families ndash but will also be open to members of the public, who may be walking past in the nearby Windsor Gardens, and fancy popping in for a coffee and a cake.The UKrsquos leading terminal illness charity provides round-the-clock expert care and support to people living with a terminal illness, and their families at the Bridgeman Road Hospice. Marie Curie also provides support to people in their own homes, and its Information and Support Line now also features clinical nurse specialists who are available for any clinical support needed.The work to create the new cafeacute has been funded by the Hodge Foundation, who also supported the refurbishment of the hospicersquos Day Therapy and Outpatients Unit in .At the opening, cakes from the hospicersquos catering team were showcased, with staff, volunteers and patients joining Suzanne and the Hodge Foundation to enjoy welsh cakes and tea and coffee.Further works at the hospice, funded by a Legacy gt from the estate of Mrs Seaward have included the installation of a Spa bathroom on both inpatient units.There has also been further maintenance work carried out alongside the bathroom and cafeacute works. The works have been unveiled in a year in which the hospice is due to celebrate its th year.Sarah Lloyd-Davies, hospice manager, said: ldquoWe are so grateful to the Hodge Foundation for once again supporting vital work to not only allow us to continue to provide expert end of le care and support to people living with a terminal illness, and their families, but also to help us expand our reach to the community in Penarth.ldquoWe want people to understand more about the work we do here, and are excited to open our cafeacute doors and encourage people to come in and have conversations with us about end of le care.ldquoThank you also to the estate of Mrs Seaward for allowing us to create two relaxing and calming Spa bathrooms for patients, which help elevate the service we can provide at the hospice.Volunteer Ian Spence, who has been volunteering on reception for  years, is now also spending some hours helping in the cafeacute.He said: ldquoIt makes me feel good about myself. I get to give something back to the community, or rather put something into it.ldquoThe hospice is such a warm place to come to and the staff are all fantastic at making everyone feel welcome.Suzanne, who has previously visited the hospice with brother and Olympian Colin Jackson, said: ldquoItrsquos been a pleasure to officially open the new Marie Curie Cafeacute at the charityrsquos Cardf and the Vale Hospice in Penarth.ldquoMeeting the staff, volunteers and families and hearing stories about the care provided here for people living with a terminal illness has been inspiring. I wish the hospice every luck with their new venture, and hope it will encourage more people to talk about end of le with their loved ones.The Marie Curie cafeacute is currently open from .am to pm Monday to Friday, with plans to expand hours with trained volunteers.If you would like to volunteer, contact the hospice on    or visit www.mariecurie.org.uk volunteering article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. face fines of poundthey do not pick up their petsrsquo faeces at sports pitches or other public spaces, and there would also be seasonal bans on some beaches.The sports pitch ban was dropped following public opposition as a petition signed by , people opposed the move.But a consultation answered by , people found per cent supported the banning of dogs from marked sports pitches.Councillor Kevin have of keeping faeces off sports pitches is having a blanket ban so that any dog on there, the owner can be prosecuted.ldquoWho on earth do they think they are  These members of the public who have pitch ban but agreed it should be an offence for dog owners not to clean up after their pets.Council leader John Thomas has previously said the council has taken peoplersquos views into account and engagement. title: view from westminster stephen doughty
story: Last Wednesday, MPs had the opportunity to participate in indicative votes on ious Brexit-related motions.This unusual step came after an amendment was passed securing parliamentary time for debate and a series of votes on Brexit scenarios, to see which,any, might command a majority in the House of Commons.Following this, on Friday the Prime Minister brought her botched deal back to the house again, after what can only be described as political lsquotrickery of the highest orderrsquo.But yet again she was defeated, this time by  votes.This was another huge defeat despite increasingly desperate efforts by the Government to try and cajole people in the last few hours before the vote.I am not prepared to support a blindfold Brexit - so I voted NO. Surely it should be three strikes and out for this deal now And so on Monday, further indicative votes were held as MPs once again took control of parliamentary business ndash despite attempts by the government to shut down our debate before it started.Supporting the move to hold these further indicative votes on Monday, I said: ldquoI think Parliament made remarkable progress the other day in a few hours, compared with the Government, who have had two years to sort this out."It is important that we not only have the opportunity to make further progress tonight, but,necessary, a small amount of time on Wednesday to get to where we need to be, so that Parliament can take control and we can move forward together as a House.And so on Monday evening, there was a hugely signicant result placing a Peoplersquos Vote as the top option for resolving the impasse, with a Customs Union only narrowly missing out as well.I voted the same way as I did last week ndash for a Customs Union for a Peoplersquos Vote, and to revoke Article we face a No Deal Brexit.Itrsquos time for the PM to compromise for the good of the country.We all need to work together to find a solution.We need a credible Brexit option to be put to a public vote in a final say, with the option on the ballot paper to Remain, in order to find a way through this crisis. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: view from the senedd vaughan gething
story: That date has come and gone.Instead we now face the real possibility of crashing out of the EU without a deal on Friday April .We are still no closer to determining what our relationship with Europe will look like than we were two years ago.Understandably, I have been contacted by a number of constituents who look at the shambles in Westminster and just want to know what is going on.Since my last update Parliament has twice rejected Theresa Mayrsquos Brexit deal by large majorities.MPs have taken control of business in Westminster and the UK Government is openly fighting with itself.On Monday MPs debated for the second time alternative visions for Brexit.The proposals to stay in the Customs Union and for a confirmatory public vote had the greatest support ndash and more support than Theresa Mayrsquos deal ndash but nothing had a majority.The choice of the UK Government to run down the clock have made the prospect of leaving the EU without a deal more likely.Theresa Mayrsquos deal is plainly not going through Parliament but no deal is even more unpalatable.A lsquoNo Dealrsquo Brexit would be bad for Wales and bad for jobs here in Cardf South and Penarth.Manufacturers, trade unions and a wide range of businesses have told us that jobs and livelihoods are at risk.We have already seen that the threat of Brexit is a real factor in jobs that have already left the UK.An industry study has warned that should we leave with no deal it could result in a loss of , jobs, with , of these jobs in Wales.It would cost the jobs of families that I represent.In my government role I have met with health and social care leaders to discuss the impact of a no deal Brexit and to plan our response.We want to ensure an uninterrupted supply of medication and secure the rights of EU nationals working within Wales.Last week I announced the acquisition of a warehouse in south Wales to provide additional storage health and care equipment to ensure there is a continuity of supply for Wales.The Welsh Government has also set up a Business Wales portal to help businesses in Wales prepare for Brexit.It has also created a poundmillion fund to help businesses prepare for the challenges of Brexit.I would urge businesses in Cardf South and Penarth to visit the Business Wales portal and find out about the support that is available.However all of our preparations cannot remove the risk of disruption.A no deal would be highly damaging for our health and care system and the people who rely upon it.I cannot overstate how much time energy and effort has been soaked up in preparing for a No Deal instead of improving our health and care system.No Deal is not a consequence free choice.It is a scandalous waste of our resources and the commitment of our staff.Politicians who bravely talk about a managed No Deal have not had to confront the realities of preparing for it or the scale of waste and damage it would cause.The most troubling aspect of Brexit has been that the isions within the UK are growing.For all my disappointment, Parliament is not enemy territory, as Nigel Farage claimed. That anger and stoking of ision is dangerous and irresponsible.At that same rally we saw a leader of the far right who is a convicted violent racist criminal being applauded on stage.That should not make any us proud regardless of how we voted.The biggest threat to the union of the UK comes from a No Deal.It would not only destabilise politics in Northern Ireland but it would almost certainly guarantee another Scottish independence referendum.More turmoil that would not turn back the tide of austerity or add a single extra penny into our schools, the NHS or any other public service that we rely upon.I do not believe a ided UK Parliament can make a choice for the next generation of our ided countries.I was proud to sponsor two coaches and march alongside more than a million members of the public, including many people from Cardf South and Penarth calling for a Peoplersquos Vote.We need to go back to the people with a choice between a Brexit deal that Parliament can agree and our current deal within the EU.There is no simple choice to the isions that we face but I would as ever be interested to hear views from my constituents. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: victoria primary pupils clean penarth beach after inspiring visit
story: As a part of their science topic of Habitats, Year Three pupils from Victoria Primary School, Penarth recently had a visit from the National Marine Aquarium.The aquarium held several fascinating workshops for the children to take part in.The aquarium made use of cutting-edge technology, including Virtual Reality headsets.Using the headsets, the children were able to lsquoersquo more than m down into the ldquoMidnight Zone.The Midnight Zone is one of the deepest, darkest areas of the ocean, and the children had the chance to see the predators and their prey in action.They also explored the food chains found in the seas and oceans of our world.They further examined the impact of plastic on these food chains and their habitats.Following these workshops, Year Three decided to undertake a beach clean on Penarth beach.Equipment was loaned by Keep Wales Tidy, the Welsh environmental charity.The youngsters did exceptionally well on their beach clean, collecting three full bags of rubbish in  minutes.They discussed dferent types of rubbish found, where it could have come from and its impact on the beach habitat and the ecosystem. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: new kymin park group to guide future of venue
story: The Kymin, a house and garden overlooking the pier and popular for weddings, had been under threat due to funding constraints, as the Penarth Times previously reported.Penarth Town Council has now said the site will close next year, and will not take bookings from March .The leader of Penarth council Cllr Rhiannon Birch said: ldquoThe town council is proud to have operated The Kymin for the people of Penarth and its visitors for four decades, under a licence from the Vale of Glamorgan CouncilldquoWe had sought a more secure tenure of the site, through Community Asset Transfer or medium-long term lease.ldquoThis would have allowed the financial investment required in the venue but these approaches have been declined by the Vale council.ldquoWith no security of tenure, the council cannot commit expenditure required and has no choice but to close.ldquoWe are proud of the events and hires hosted by the building and the valuable green space it provides in Penarth.ldquoAs the council is no longer able to operate the Kymin, we are now glad to be able to offer community hire space at West House Community Hub, following the improvements to the public community garden under the Penarth in Bloom project.Vale of Glamorgan Council managing director Rob Thomas added: ldquoIt was entirely the Penarth Town Councilrsquos decision to close the building early and prior to the termination date in .ldquoThe Vale of Glamorgan Council was surprised to learn of the decision to close and leave it vacant for the rest of the notice period.ldquoThe council feels that this decision is to the detriment of those who use the site, local residents and the wider Penarth Community, but the Vale council has no power to force the town council to keep the building open,they chose not to.A group is now being set is being set up concerned residents to help guide the future of the Kymin Park.Richard Parry, a regular user of the park, has asked anyone interested in the outcome of the park to attend a meeting.Mr Parry said: "The Kymin Park is an important and lovely part of the town landscape. It is, in many ways, a hidden corner of Penarth with a unique and special character."The future plans for the house will no doubt be a subject of local interest and concern, but in the meantime a number of local people have expressed interest in forming a voluntary group called "The Friends of the Kymin Park."This group would aim to promote enjoyment of the park as public pleasure grounds."Wed also invite both councils to keep us informed of developments so that "the friends of the Kymin Park" could also be a source of good information about arrangements of access and enjoyment of the park during the time that the park management negotiations are resolved," added Mr Parry."Anyone interested is welcome to come to a meeting on Tuesday at .pm in Foxys Deli,  Victoria Road, Penarth to discuss the formation of a group "The Friends of the Kymin Park", specically focused on supporting and developing public enjoyment of the park grounds." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: residents urged to sign petition to ban all animals travelling performances ahead of circus mondao
story: Circus Mondao, a travelling showcase with trapeze artists, clowns, stunts and animals, will stop in the Vale from April  to .But a petition has been launched to ban the use of all animals in circuses in Wales, including by Circus Mondao.ldquoItrsquos just cruel, forcing animals to behave like that, said Linda Joyce Jones, who started the petition. ldquoThey donrsquot want to be there, and theyrsquore forced to travel constantly.Petra Jackson, the ringmistress, looks after the animals for Circus Mondao.ldquoWe look after the animals in our care, she said. ldquoWe follow stringent government standards and guidelines. We place our animalrsquos welfare at the top of our list, and they only make up a very small portion of the show.ldquoTheyrsquore not just animals, theyrsquore part of our family. They want for nothing with us.ldquoThey do travel, but its no more intensive than an average commuter bringing along their dog in the car.ldquoWhen we pitch up, they stay in large, custom built and comfortable enclosures. Wersquore staying at a venue in Rhoose rather than Sully this year, because it is a more secluded area which the animals prefer.Animal welfare is a devolved issue.While it is an offence under the Animal Welfare Act  to fail to provide for an animal properly, a bill will be put forward this year by the Welsh Government to ban wild animals in circuses entirely, though some animals - such as dogs or ponies - are not covered. England will introduce a similar bill in .A public consultation, carried out in Wales in November  and published in January , found that out of , responses,  per cent of responses were behind a ban on wild animals in circuses.But a total of , of these responses were identical, from campaign group Born Free.More than  local authorities in the UK have a ban on animals in circuses, but the Vale council is not among them. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: penarth inventors latest design the zigzag to be produced entirely in welsh factories
story: John Tomalin-Reeves, , has spent the past three years designing and perfecting the ZIGZAG, an outdoor oven designed and made entirely in Wales.Whether itrsquos slow-cooked shanks, sizzled seabass or a speedy margherita, ZIGZAG is designed for budding chefs and enthusiastic cooks who enjoy the great outdoors.The product features an innovative floating baking stone which allows flames to heat food from beneath as well as over the top to create a dual heat source, speeding up cooking time and adding flavour.John has launched a crowdfunding campaign to help get the ZIGZAG into mass production and is asking for help from the people of Wales.Unlike most crowdfunders the final product is already complete.By backing the campaign, pledgers will receive the oven at a reduced price. They will also be supporting local communities and families as once orders are underway, the product will go into mass production in Welsh factories.Much of the product has been made in a family-run steel fabricators in Ferndale in the Rhondda.John said: ldquoI love the fact that the ZIGZAG has been made within  miles of my home in Penarth. Irsquove visited the factory literally hundreds of times in the last three years and that wouldnrsquot have been possibleit was made in China, but what it proves more than anything is that businessmen and women really need to look thoroughly at whatrsquos under their noses.ldquoIrsquove been amazed by the talent Irsquove seen on these shores - there are some incredible businesses here doing some world beating things, and they need our support. Regardless of how you voted in the referendum, whether wersquore in or out we should all be proud of what we produce on this island and Irsquom here to show you that itrsquos possible to create a great product without having to go to the Far East.ldquoIt has taken me three years to develop the ZIGZAG - from the seed of an idea to the living and breathing product you can see today. I want you to support our crowdfunding campaign so we can give a boost to the factories in Wales which have supported our development. Theyrsquore ready to make your ZIGZAG now!Factory boss, Jason Keetch, who runs the factory making the ZIGZAG, said: "It has been an absolute pleasure working on the ZIGZAG with John.The majority of our workload consists of manufacturing sub components for larger designs so we rarely get to make a recognisably finished product like this. Seeing first hand the progression of the design and working so closely with John on it has made this project feel extra special.ldquoMy whole team are proud that the ZIGZAG is a fully Welsh product and that we have been a part of its story. Wersquore excited to see where it now goes!Those who pledge their support and buy a ZIGZAG in the first -days of the crowdfunder, which ends on Sunday  May, will benefit from an early bird price of pound.To find out more, visit: igg.me at zigzag-oven article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: penarth makes the sunday times list of top ten places to live in wales
story: The town has retained its spot in the top ten list, published annually by The Sunday Times.The papers "Best Places to Live Guide " was published on Sunday April .The article praised the town, noting that "The best place to live in Cardf isnt Cardf," but a short journey down the coast.Praise was heaped on several of the towns independent retailers and venues, including interiors shop Benjamins, grocer Windsor Fruit Stores and the Ocho Lounge.Approval for its public spaces, Belle Vue, Cosmeston Lakes Country Park and Penarth Head, as well as the iconic Penarth Pier, was lavished upon the town.The article further quoted Mel Grfin, owner of independent bookshop Grfin Books, as saying the town had a "distinct identity" despite being close to Cardf, and that it has "a strong community spirit."The paper finishes by summing up why The Sunday Times loves it: "Therersquos nothing wrong with Penarth posh".The town of Crickhowell topped the list of best places to live in Wales. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: view from westminster stephen doughty
story: Irsquom keeping up my focus on non-Brexit issues though, and have spoken in the Commons on a range of matters including internet safety, plastic pollution and police cuts, all of which affect or matter to constituents in Penarth and Cardf.This week the Government announced a crackdown on internet and social media companies over their failure to tackle extremist and terrorist content online, and content that poses a risk to children - after pressure from myself and others on the Home Affairs and Digital Committees.In response I said: ldquoIrsquom pleased that they appear to have listened to many of the concerns raised by the Home Affairs Committee, including by me and the Chair."I look forward to action on that, but may I press the Secretary of State further on the integrity of our elections, our referendums and indeed our democracy on a day-to-day basis "Particularly in light of recent revelations about millions in dark money that is being spent on advertising to influence votes and to whip up hatred against Members of this House, does he not agree that we need action today, rather than wait months I also raised the issue of funding for South Wales Police in PMQs.I said: ldquoSouth Wales Police is doing a brilliant job in Cardf South and Penarth, in spite of pressures, dealing with kne crime, drugs, domestic violence and so much more, but it does not get capital city funding, unlike other capitals, which makes the pressure worse."Will the Prime Minister look at this again urgently Locally, Irsquove received messages from concerned parents following letters from Penarth and Vale schools about funding and resourcing problems.This is a complex issue but I share the worry and concern felt by many teachers and parents.Although education is a devolved matter, the impact of austerity from the UK government over nine years has impacted on Welsh budgets.Irsquom already in touch with our local councillor team and Vaughan Gething AM, and personally raised the concerns with the First Minister this weekend.Irsquoll provide further information as I have it and suggest concerned parents contact Vaughan Gething AM and local councillors who are best placed to advise on the situation. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey title: view from the senedd vaughan gething
story: Our son attends a local primary school and I completely understand why parents and carers are concerned about the message from head teachers.I recently met the Penarth cluster head teachers to hear directly from them about the pressure on school budgets.Parents were encouraged to contact me so I think itrsquos appropriate that I respond publicly.I donrsquot want to respond with a party political response but I do want to set out honestly how the choices made at UK Government, Welsh Government and the Vale council affect school funding.It is an undeniable fact that as we enter the th year of UK Government austerity our spending choices are more and more dficult.The Welsh Government has pound.billion less to spend as a result.To be fair the Conservative leader of the Vale council has said in correspondence with me and in a public council meeting that he wants austerity to stop.We have made dferent choices in Wales compared to England.The Welsh Government has chosen to prioritise health spending in our budget.That means that the pound.billion cut in our budget has affected local government and schools.Local government and schools spending has been much better protected in Wales. In England the local government budget has seen cuts that are twice as large as here in Wales and school spending has been much better protected.When I met Penarth head teachers I was honest about our choice to protect NHS spending.Health has consistently been the top priority of the public and I still face demands from all parties to spend even more money on the NHS.To deliver signicantly more money for schools and the local government budget would mean taking money out of the NHS.Keeping our commitment to the NHS affects every other public service, including our schools. That is the reality of nearly a decade of austerity.That does not mean that schools have been abandoned.For example the Welsh Government chose to increase funding to our st Century Schools programme. That means more new schools like the Penarth Learning Community and thanks to the budget deal secured by Labour councillors more money to renovate Victorian schools in the Vale.This year changes to teachers pensions by the UK Government have created a multi-million pound hole in school budgets. The UK Government only passed on  per cent of the costs to Wales. The Welsh Government funded the missing  per cent but that is money that canrsquot be spent somewhere .Despite the fact that local government in Wales has a much better funding deal than across the border in England I recognise that our councils have an incredibly dficult challenge setting a budget.We all saw that in the Vale, where nearly half the ruling Conservative group refused to back the budget proposal from their own leadership. There is a choice to be made between reducing services or raising council tax. Even after council tax rises most councils are still reducing services.Education and social services are the largest spending areas for local councils. Each council decides their own spending priorities and dferent councils have made dferent choices.The local funding formula for schools in the Vale was reviewed and simplied by the previous Labour administration and agreed by local head teachers. Itrsquos simpler and more transparent as a result.Itrsquos disappointing that the Vale Council leadership refuses to recognise that it has any responsibility for school funding choices. For example Cardf council has put a larger proportion of its budget into schools than the Vale.I welcome the Welsh Government review into the local authority funding formula. The wider review should provide an updated picture.However that in itself does not mean that there will be more money flowing into school budgets in the Vale.That still comes back to choices about how much money we are prepared to invest in our public services rather than a competition between public services that each of us value. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: long awaited dinas powys bypass route chosen
story: Vale of Glamorgan Council has announced a route for the bypass between Cardf and Barry that it will take forward into an outline business case.The route would run from theeast of Dinas Powys connecting with theA at Cardf Road and the Merrie Harrier Junction and may include a new roundabout to connectivity to Murch Road.Improvements to public transport and cycling and walking routes are also being considered.Vale of Glamorgan councilrsquos ruling body on April  approved plans to progress exclusively with the route, known as the lsquoGreen and Pink Route,rsquo into the Welltag stage two process ndash which involves preparing an outline business case to the Welsh Government.The council had been considering a route for the bypass which connects the Merrier Harrier junction to theB Sully Moors Road and HayesRoad roundabout, known as the lsquoBlue Route,rsquo but this has now been dropped from the process.The councilrsquos cabinet also agreed to ask the Welsh Government for pound, to complete the Welltag stage two work but the council would seek ldquoalternative sources of fundingCardf Bay does not provide the money.A public consultation would be held before a full business case is put together.Emma Reed, the councilrsquos head of neighbourhood services and transport, said at a council meeting on March  that a -week consultation could be launched before the summer break in August.The meeting on April  heard the Dinas Powys Bypass Steering Group sent an email to the cabinet two weeks ago asking them to suspend the decision.But council leader John Thomas said the cabinet should make the decision as ldquowe have not heard anything since.ldquoIf we donrsquot get on with it itrsquos going to be further delays, he said. article_url   content_id   site_id title: view from westminster stephen doughty
story: The new deadline of October  meant that we did not crash out of the EU last Friday with no deal - the nightmare clf-edge scenario that would have done so much harm.This extension is very good news indeed, and Irsquom grateful to our EU partners for their tolerance of our domestic political crisis, and for their shared desire to prevent a catastrophic no-deal Brexit.This provides us with time to agree a deal in Parliament and then put that to the people for a final say in a confirmatory vote ndash which I believe is the only way to end this chaos.After news of the delay was officially announced in the Commons by the PM, I told her again why a Peoplersquos Vote is the only way to break the deadlock.I said: ldquoI welcome this extension and the ruling-out of a catastrophic no deal."I also welcome the talks going on between our two parties, because it is important that we try to find consensus and attempt to break the deadlock."However, I warn the Prime Minister that attempting to de-couple the issue of a deal from whether it goes back to the people for their confirmation will not be acceptable to many people on the Opposition Benches, or indeed an increasing number on her own."Will she recognise that the only way to break the deadlock will be a confirmatory vote, putting this issue back to the people In response, the PM could only offer her usual, tired, Brexit-means-Brexit answer.On the weekend I was in North Wales for the annual Welsh Labour Conference.Itrsquos always a great opportunity to catch up with dferent organisations and campaigns, to discuss local and national issues.Among others, I met my own GMB union to talk about taxis in Cardf and civilian policing staff the Police Federation to talk about police drivers, funding and the challenges of rising crime and demand on services my sister party the Co-operative Party to support their campaign on food justice the Terrence Higgins Trust to support their campaigns on PreP and sexual health the BHF to focus on CPR skills and the importance of teaching first aid Citizens Advice to wish them happy th birthday and thank them for the support they provide locally and WWF to support their campaigns on nature and climate change. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey title: vale of glamorgans business rate relief plans revealed

result of a merger of three formerly separate schools: Ashgrove School, Ysgol Maes Dyfan and Ysgol Erwrsquor Delyn.Ashgrove was a school for pupils with autism, Maes Dyfan catered for pupils with moderate to severe learning dficulties and Erwrsquor Delyn was for pupils with profound and multiple learning and medical needs.Ysgol y Deri now caters for all of these needs under one roof.There are  pupils, ranging in age from  to , with almost as many staff, at about .Pupils are drawn from the Vale of Glamorgan as well as from the neighbouring local authorities of Cardf, Newport, Bridgend, Caerphilly, Rhondda Cynon Taf and Swansea.I was first shown to the Early Intervention Building, where children from the age of three to five were taught.These students had been identied from a young age as having autism or other behavioural and learning dficulties.There I was introduced to Elias, aged five. He shook my hand, and showed me some of the facilities.I was shown how the ldquoMagic Carpet works, an interactive board on the floor. It lit up with a flower pattern, that moved and shimmered when stood on.I was then invited to the soft play room, where Elias flung himself over the equipment, scampering above me and the assistant. He grinned for the camera.Ysgol Y Deri particularly shines in the creative approaches it takes to putting its students first.In the big school I was shown to ldquoThe Holodeck, a Star-Trek-esque room filled with projectors and touchscreen sensitive walls.There was a French quiz projected across the walls, and the students jumped around the room selecting the correct words.The sensory experience was not only impressively creative, but vital to some studentsrsquo learning.The school has many similar rooms built to offer a multi-disciplinary team approach to the youngsters and offer a fully holistic experience.They have a large team of therapists on site, including nurses, occupational therapists, speech and language therapists, physiotherapists, music therapists and play therapists.They also offer a huge range of interventions, designed to put their pupilsrsquo happiness and education at the forefront.They offer yoga, mindfulness lessons, climbing, gardening, wood work, pet therapy, rebound therapy and hydrotherapy, as just a small example. Timetables are crafted to suit inidualsrsquo needs, as some pupils respond better than others to certain lessons.I was shown to a classroom where a group of seven students worked on their laptops.These students were proud of their work and excited to talk about maths.We were then ushered through as a group for a photo with next doorrsquos class, a group with physical disabilities.The students waited patiently as overhead cranes helped those who could not walk into position.Everyone smiled. Thumbs and peace signs were flashed.Afterwards, a Learning Support Assistant tapped me on the shoulder and reminded me to take a photo of Caitlyn.I pointed the camera at her, and Caitlinrsquos smile immediately reached her ears.Maxine, a fellow student, told me how proud her family were of her and her work.The happiness of every one of the pupils is palpable, filling every area of the school, as does the pride of the teachers.ldquoWe have our pupils come back in every now and then, said Stacey Long, the schoolrsquos transition officer.She helps pupils move on from the school and into adult le.ldquoThey always tell me how much the school meant to them, how helpful it was in getting a job.ldquoWe try hard to get pupils ready for adult le where we can.ldquoWe have a coffee shop on campus where several students get plenty of work experience.The curriculum covers both the national curriculum as well as general le skills.One interactive quiz I was shown could be rapidly switched from a lesson on the Great Fire of London, to a quiz on which materials go in which recycle bin.There are plenty of extra-curricular activities on offer too, including choir and youth club and regular trips outside of school.I was given a glimpse into a gym, along with a music recording room with plenty of recording equipment, and the school radio room.Outside, pupils are given a huge playground with an outdoor classroom, space to play sport, a climbing wall and little walled off sections for each of the primary classes.Developer Barratt Homes was also on the site, building a sensory garden for students to enjoy.Last week a group of pupils of ying abilities went on a trip to Paris, where they were involved with ious Comenius [European Union education] projects and forged links with numerous schools in other European countries. Several pupils couldnrsquot wait to tell me about it, showing off photos.Chris Britten, the head teacher of Ysgol Y Deri, said: ldquoWe work with every child. They are all dferent and we treat every one as an inidual. We meet their needs so they can flourish, both in school and after they leave. He is immensely proud of his staff and pupils.Itrsquos easy to see why. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: sun shines on penarth easter celebrations
story: The Friends of Belle Vue Park held an Easter celebration" Sun shines on Penarth Easter celebrationsThe crowd midway through the Dinas Powys Walk of Witness" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentEASTER over Penarth and the Vale of Glamorgan was a sun-drenched affair, with churches, chapels and clubs all banding together to put on a host of services and entertainment.The sun shone on the Easter Walk of Witness in Dinas Powys. Members of local chapels and churches processed from the Twyn through Dinas Powys passed Tesco at Nica, ending at Bethesda Chapel.Fish and chips sustained around  walkers by the end of the evening.Rev Jon Davis of the Baptist Church and the Revs Carole and Phil Challis of the Methodists led the service with the first hymn, Light of the World. The reading of Markrsquos gospel was by David Cocks.At Nica the hymn lsquoHere is love, vast as the oceanrsquo was sung.The next reading was given by Ciara McAlpine. Finally at Tesco the hymn lsquoWhen I survey the wondrous crossrsquo was sung, with Sarah Long reading.Matt Lewis of Bethesda commissioned the new cross and led the short service at Bethesda.Many thanks go to Councillor John Fanshaw for the loan of the excellent PA system. Everyone was kept safe by the traffic marshal Brian West.The Friends of Belle Vue Park held an Easter celebration of their own.They said: ldquoWe had a fantastic time with crafts, games, seed planting and selfies.ldquoThere were so many amazing Easter hat designs, it was hard to choose!ldquoThanks to all the hard-working volunteers who made the event possibleAs well as events held by churches and chapels, Easter egg hunts were a recurring theme for many venues.Cosmeston Lakes hosted their own hunt over the course of the weekend, inviting people to try their luck at solving clues for prizes.Llantwit Major Surf Lesaving Club held an Easter egg hunt on Easter Monday, with face painting, name the bunny, refreshments and hot drinks.St Fagans National Museum of History held their own ldquoBig Museum Easter Trail, asking visitors to solve clues and follow the trail around the museum infor an ldquoegg-citing prize. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice.
